identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Molly Ivins. The panel examines the concepts of verification and intelligence related to nuclear arms limitation treaties, specifically the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979. Coming from several different perspectives, the panelists discuss the difficulties in determining the size and capabilities of the Soviet nuclear arsenal. Katherine Camp provides political context, followed by Daniel Graham's in-depth analysis of the diplomatic and strategic landscape. Thomas Halsted makes the distinction between verification for treaty purposes and intelligence for national security purposes. Marvin Leibstone shares the other panelists’ concerns about the difficulties of verification, while questioning the end result of strategic arms limitation treaties.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#2: Television broadcasting of news -- Objectivity -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Gary Blonston. Someone argues that the media does not have a liberal bias, but a conservative bias and that unbiased reporting can only come from independently owned newspapers. Someone describes the process of publishing a book. Someone states that various major reporting agencies are owned by the same people and this is due to the high costs of televised reporting and film making. Someone compares the media in the U.S. and Great Britain and notes that increased competition often does not equate to diversity in coverage.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Sam Kuczun. The panel discusses the media's coverage of and relationship with Ronald Reagan. Robert Brictson addresses the concept of “doublespeak” in politics, arguing that Reagan used it as a technique to foment fear of communism. Margot Adler examines what responsibilities the press has, especially relating to the office of the presidency. Molly Ivins challenges two assumptions: that the press is a uniform entity, and that objectivity is a desirable journalistic goal. Audience questions cover foreign policy, the economy, and the state of American news media.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Bernhard Goetz: Trial by the Press
description#1: Moderated by Salvador Rodriguez del Pino. The panel discusses Bernhard Goetz, who shot four young black men attempting to mug him on the subway in New York in 1984. Peter Tauber argues that illegally carrying weapons in public is a threat to public safety. Margot Adler places the issue in the broader context of safety in New York City at the time, and argues that the city is not as dangerous as most people think. Molly Ivins extends Adler's point to argue that irrational fear is the source of the problem. During the question and answer session, the panelists discuss the media's role in perpetuating New York's dangerous image.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Olivia Lopez Carter . The panel discusses race relations in America during the Reagan administration. Molly Ivins argues that conservative domestic policy cuts social services, negatively affecting ethnic minorities. Sam Papich demonstrates how the NCAA discriminates against young Black men in college athletics, relating stories from his time in the FBI prosecuting illegal gambling operations. Barbara Smith traces systematic oppression in America to the history of colonialism in Africa, and examines the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa.The audience question and answer period covers FBI surveillance of Martin Luther King Jr., affirmative action, and the future of South Africa.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Robert Lewis. The panelists begin by addressing Robert Lewis's concerns about how yuppies are portrayed in the media. Peter Tauber explains how the 60s generation became yuppies as well as the contradictory values of being a yuppie. Molly Ivins describes being along the "periphery" of the yuppie generation. Annette Goodheart notes that ridiculing yuppies shows society's distress about materialism and nuclear annihilation. Roger Ebert believes that there is nothing wrong with consumerism and focusing on the self. The panelists discuss whether the yuppies are still missing something, bodybuilders, the 60s, sexuality, movies, drugs, and the productivity of yuppies.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Upper Crust Doesn't Know what is Going on Below
description#1: Moderated by David M. Armstrong. Molly Ivins argues that, during the Reagan administration, economic classes in America are becoming more stratified and segregated as a result of public policy decisions. Ivins uses statistics and demographic information to make the point that the middle class is shrinking while the lower class grows. She also explores why poor people seem to be ignored by the media and the American public. Both Barry Newman and Sally Fay respond that the Reagan administration has not caused the problem, and that upward mobility still exists in America. Audience questions cover political solutions, international comparison, and further discussion of Ronald Reagan.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Barrie M. Hartman. The panel discusses the sometimes uneasy relationships between the American public, political structure, and media. Douglass Cater addresses and challenges the stereotype of the newspaper reporter in Washington. Samuel Chavkin examines the ways that government actions have affected journalism and led to self-censorship. Sidney Hyman argues that people interpret television and print journalism differently, leading to misunderstanding and tension. Molly Ivins wonders how to limit hostility toward the press while respecting the first amendment, also touching on concepts like objectivity and corrections. Audience questions address television journalism, sensationalism, and Rupert Murdoch.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Michael Newman. This panel explores the cultural impact of the game Trivial Pursuit and it’s representation of the current ‘yuppie’ generation. Mark Kramer argues that Trivial Pursuit advocates a homogenization of knowledge and equates ‘trivial’ pop culture facts to more important pieces of information. Bill Weeden ponders the definition of trivial; claiming that what is trivial and what is important is a matter of perspective. Molly Ivins explores the social status, cultural bias, and culture gap in our society that is showcased by Trivial Pursuit. James Jackson maintains that we are always taught to not do trivial things, but many upper class activities (such as sailing) are trivial.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Giora Bernstein. The panel attempts to define and discover the origins of “yuppies” in America. Molly Ivins identifies materialism as a defining characteristic, and wonders whether media coverage of yuppies will continue after the 1980s. Ivins and Stuart Schoffman agree that the term is a media creation, but Schoffman argues that it reflects a growing materialism in America. Peter Tauber disparages yuppie culture with jokes about Walkmen and designer water, concluding with an exhortation to ignore the trivial and improve the world.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#4: United States -- Foreign relations -- Latin America
subject#5: Latin America -- Foreign relations -- United States
description#1: Moderator not identified. Phil Campbell argues that the U.S. policy of containment translates into the idea that revolutionary, nationalist movements in the third world are synonymous with the Soviet Union, and reactionary policies to these movements has fostered anti-American feelings throughout the world. John Tirman asserts the necessity to leave Nicaragua on its own without outside interference, and maintains that Nicaragua should not be at the forefront of U.S. policy. Reed Brody provides a brief history of the Nicaraguan conflict and Reagan’s role as a contra. Molly Ivins focuses on internal politics, illuminating the debate between those who argue we should never have supported right-wing dictators while others argue we did not support these dictators enough.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Raybon. This panel discusses the changing relationship and roles between men and women. Thomas Powers argues that men are resisting women’s attempts to redefine their roles in society, and he asserts that men and women are equals in nearly all aspects of life. Clara Wainwright illuminates the necessity of a group setting where men and women can discuss issues, whether gender specific or extending to the whole human species. Bob Wilber shares his experiences with women (or the lack thereof) in his field of work: nuclear weaponry. Molly Ivins introduces varying roles of women throughout history and subtle differences between the two sexes.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Women Journalists: The Girls on the Bus
subject#3: Women in the mass media industry
description#1: Moderated by Kathi George. Molly Ivins shares her experience as a women journalist in a nearly all male dominated institution, stating that it was only her excessive height that allowed her to really break into the kind of work she wanted. Margot Adler discusses sexual harassment she faced in the workplace, as well as the immense pressure on journalists and the high suicide rate that accompanies the profession. Myra Lea MacPherson discusses the discrimination she faced and the need she felt to act like one of the boys. The Q&A session explores gender roles and ethical issues in reporting.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#5: Spraying and dusting residues in agriculture
description#1: Moderated by Edwin Crow. Molly Ivins discusses the current political situation in Texas and shares stories of outlandish political behavior. Michael Stoff explores the transition between old politicians and new politicians, arguing that Texas will be a political barometer for the rest of the country as it transitions to a new form of politics. Tani Adams recounts her work as a chemical activist and the institutionalization of the battle against agrarian pesticides. Whitley Strieber describes the polarization between Texans and Mexican-Americans. He shares stories of his own family’s role in Texan history and his encounters with politicians.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Leo Cabell. Amy Edmondson argues that the hatred of learning is a learned process, claiming it is human nature to want to learn. David Finkle discusses the duality of the meaning of the phrase ‘hatred of learning’, and explores how some people hate both learning and those who have learning. He ponders why there are some who resist learning, and questions the historical background of learning. Molly Ivins argues there are three sources of the hatred of learning: sense of failure, the perception that people use knowledge as an oppressive weapon, and the idea that learning results in abandonment of former identity. Michael Stoff claims learning is an ongoing process and concurs with Edmondson’s belief that it is human nature to learn. He explores American society’s treatment of teachers and the possible reasons for failing teachers.

description#1: Chaired by Horace B. Holmes. [Molly Ivins and Myra MacPherson were scheduled to participate, but neither is heard on this recording.] Josiah Thompson displays and analyzes the Abraham Zapruder film of Kennedy’s assassination. He invites the audience to determine the exact events of the day as the footage is reviewed frame by frame. He provides background information as well as results of the Warren Commission and the botched autopsy. In the Q&A session he speculates on possible conspiracies and reflects on the search for truth and justice.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Marie Fagan. [Molly Ivins was scheduled to participate on this panel, but is not heard on this recording.] Robert Cornet vehemently argues that the media do not promote addiction, and advocates the necessity of learning the power of rhetoric in order to defend oneself against the persuasive powers of media. Thomas Adams agrees with Cornet in that there is no actual causation between media and addiction, and explores why people first start using drugs and subsequent media targeting of race and gender groups. Bruce Sumner ponders the significance of the first amendment and the societal origins of addiction, agreeing with his panelists that the media is merely a reflection of society, and does not instigate addiction.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Religion and Politics: Does it Sell?
description#1: Moderated by Michael Newman. Molly Ivins begins by talking about the conjunction of fundamental religion and politics. Ivins explains why fundamentalism is attractive in the American society at this time. Roger Ebert talks about how a person with the greatest faith has the greatest doubt. Ebert then states three things  spontaneity, content, and interaction  religious television has that ordinary television usually lacks. Margot Adler talks about how spirituality reality is like the natural world. Christopher Bigsby explains why he doesn't fundamentally understand the United States.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Chaired by Beverly Sears. This panel explores religious fundamentalism around the world and seeks to discover motivations, causes, and long term effects of this zealous religious movement. Jonathan Broder discusses fundamentalist religion in the Middle East and recounts a brief history of the area to explain the emergence of fundamentalist terrorists. Molly Ivins describes American fundamentalism, and provides reasons and motivations behind this religious movement. Sally Fay explores the power of fundamentalism and the place of social issues in religious fervor.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Zeus, Energy, and the Hairy Man Within
description#1: Moderated by Olivia Edwards. This panel explores the changing role of men and their relationship to women during the women’s movement. Stuart Schoffman introduces the work of Robert Bly and discusses the necessity of creating an image of maleness that is both sexual and sensitive. Michael Stoff shares his own experience in a time of changing gender roles and his own familiarity with the isolation of sensitive men. Molly Ivins counters Schoffman’s point, arguing that Robert Bly isn’t relevant and men are just using Bly’s work as an excuse to demonize the women’s movement. Laurie Taylor contemplates the very nature of talking about oneself and the rhetoric used to describe men and women.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jennifer Heath. This panel discusses flaws and problems in the field of journalism, particularly issues in producing marketable content that is also factually correct. Molly Ivins reflects on the history of journalism and claims that omission in journalism results from attempts to reduce complex stories to two sided conflicts. Peter Pringle acknowledges corruption and the inward focus of journalists and discusses problems in British journalism. Lee Allen maintains that a free press and flow of information is what contributes to the success of the world; he explores the difficulties of crafting marketable news for a wide audience. Francois Xavier Lovat shares his anger with the mechanisms of journalism and recounts stories of his struggle for justice in journalism.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Georgiana Colville. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how the trend towards teenage movies is over. Ebert then discusses two types of teenage movies: dead teenager movies and horny teenager movies. Molly Ivins states that there are other kinds of films aimed towards young people other than the ones Ebert has mentioned. Johnn Mendel briefly states how people are getting a better shot at film. Habibullah Tegey talks about how the video cassette machine is not only affecting the present market of the movie, but also the social changes and social relations in American society.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Leslie Eaon. The panel explores the correlation between high priced food and upper class consumers. John Brown discusses the gastronomical tour of the world now available in American restaurants and explores the prestige of cuisine. Molly Ivins recounts food horror stories of the Midwest and argues that food as a marker of prestige will not last long because it is not conspicuous enough. William Eagleton shares his food related stories as a Middle Eastern diplomat and the varying cultural norms and customs surrounding food. Andrew Neil discusses foodies in Britain and shares excerpts from a book entitled Are You a Foodie?

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Dennis Van Gerven. This panel discusses corruption in college athletics, particularly the practice of paying athletic recruits and passing illiterate athletes. Molly Ivins recounts scandals within Texas college athletics, the role of authorities in aiding the corruption of the system, and argues against paying college athletes. Robert Casper Brictson explores discrepancies in colleges regarding how they approach the athletic budget and lower academic standards for college athletes. Shepherd Brooks introduces the ‘Plantation System’ in Georgia; illiterate athletes are allowed to graduate college but are left with no life skills and unable to survive in the workforce. George Armelagos discusses the emergence of big business athletics and maintains that the new focus on money and corruption has ruined the spirit of the game. Clay Spontaine shares his own experience as a high school and college football player, and emphasizes the danger of the infantile pageantry that is present in many aspects of American society. Audience questions cover drugs, race, capitalism, and physical education.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Christopher J. Busick. The panel takes a multifaceted, humorous approach to discuss the concepts of crises and media coverage. Molly Ivins details several of these crises, including the threats of terrorism, drugs, and illiteracy. She examines the way the media covers these problems and the consequences of that coverage. Jonathan Kwitny tells humorous anecdotes about his experience writing and publishing a book. William Eagleton analyzes different types of crises, focusing on those caused by the government. Michael Elliott discusses the historical role of women in the military. Audience questions cover Margaret Thatcher, the Chadian crisis, and future trends.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Marsha Caplan. The panel discusses marriage and gender roles. June Golden presents the absent Molly Ivins' prepared remarks, which focus on public interest in unmarried women. June Golden's own remarks analyze changing roles within marriage. Sayre Seldon argues that greater independence for women has led to fewer marriages, noting that this independence is limited to privileged women. Susan Love shares her personal experience as a lesbian to illustrate the limiting effects of gender expectations. Michael Shaw faults gender stereotypes perpetuated by the media. Audience questions cover maternal and paternal roles, stereotypes, and divorce.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by David Barsamian.The panel discusses press coverage of the Iran-Contra affair. Molly Ivins analyzes the political actors and attempts to explain the media's reaction. Peter Dale Scott argues that the establishment press failed to cover the Latin American drug connection to the Contras. During panel discussion, Adam Hochschild and Molly Ivins agree that journalists learn to avoid controversial topics. Audience questions include media manipulation, libel suits, and conspiracy theories.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Howie Movshovitz. The panel discusses the state of comedy. David Finkle argues that comedy is enjoying a resurgence because of television, new comedy clubs, and excellent writing. Peter Tauber shares his experience writing comedy and analyzes the success of comedians like Jay Leno and Robin Williams. Molly Ivins relates several experiences covering Texas politics, and outlines the difference between rural and urban humor. Eric Lax discusses Woody Allen and fields audience questions about Allen's career. Audience questions cover successful comedians, freedom of speech, and the nature of satire.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Faye Johnson. The panel discusses the political left wing in the United States, especially as it relates to the 1988 presidential election. Harvey Wasserman argues that the Democratic Party was torn apart at the 1968 Democratic National Convention as a result of the Vietnam War. Molly Ivins examines and makes distinctions between liberals, radicals, and revolutionaries. Tani Adams relates her personal history to define liberals, concluding that labels are ineffective. David Twersky contests Wasserman's interpretation of 1968, and analyzes Jesse Jackson's role in the presidential election. Panel discussion and audience questions focus on the 1988 election.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Horace Lewis Sawin. The panel discusses various problems with the American media. With the help of the audience, Robert McClendon identifies problems like sensationalism, bias, and negativity, which he then traces to consumer habits. Charles-Gene McDaniel argues that journalism is an overly self-critical profession, but acknowledges that the press serves the establishment. Molly Ivins examines shortcomings of the American media in the Vietnam War and El Salvador and analyzes the role of the media in politics. Panel discussion and audience questions address the relationship between government and media, journalistic bias, and alternative media.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Leslie B. Eaton. The panel discusses the role of men in relationships. Molly Ivins argues that the question raised by the panel is inherently sexist, and that this type of thinking has negative consequences for men and women. Russell Schweickart notes the evolving definition of gender roles, and argues that men ultimately want meaning in life and a clear definition of masculinity. Mel Stewart makes a distinction between what men want and what men need and discusses the merits of polygamy. Audience questions cover the origins and future of gender roles, the concept of equality, the effects of feminism, and gender violence.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Rolf Kjolseth. The panel discusses the administration of newspaper journalism. Richard Aregood criticizes the emphasis on profits, especially by local newspaper editors. Mariana Edmonds shares her experience developing the 60 Minutes television program, questioning the distinction between news and entertainment. Jonathan Kwitny identifies several problems resulting from newspaper monopolies. Panelist discussion and audience questions continue to examine how money affects reporting. Other topics include consumer behavior, controversial reporting, and potential solutions.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by James A. Lavita. The panel discusses how media outlets gather and present news. Adam Hochschild relates personal anecdotes from his time as a reporter and argues that news is often manipulated. Simon Hoggart agrees, and identifies the problem as an overemphasis on facts and a lack of journalistic judgment. Molly Ivins makes the point that most errors are ones of omission, not commission. Audience questions cover unconscious bias, the relationship between the press and the presidency, and journalistic ethics.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Mark Constancio. The panel discusses the adversarial relationship between the legislative and executive branches in the United States. Bruce Sumner contextualizes the Social Security debate in Congress by explaining congressional budgets. Harriet Barlow argues that neither the executive branch nor the legislative branch is serving the American people effectively. Douglas Bennet attributes this failure to a lack of direction. Molly Ivins compares Ronald Reagan and George Bush to illustrate how American presidents work with the legislative branch and hurt the American people. Audience questions focus on campaign finance reform and general elections.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Bradford. The panel discusses the editorial process in print journalism, mostly from the perspective of the writer. Molly Ivins shares an anecdote about unsubstantiated claims of cocaine use by Ann Richards becoming news headlines. Simon Hoggart explains how seemingly trivial rewrites can compromise integrity. John Tierney emphasizes the broad range of editorial oversight he had as a writer. Stuart Schoffman tells stories from his stints as a writer at Time magazine and as a Hollywood screenwriter. Audience questions address objectivity in journalism, the influence of government, tabloids, gender bias, and television news.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Michael C. Ehlers. The panel discusses how and why American media neglect some current events. Charles-Gene McDaniel examines journalistic business practices to help explain why some stories are not covered. Lee Allen argues that the media are manipulated by public relations firms, and cites several examples of poor journalism. Molly Ivins discusses the media's errors of omission. Arturo Arias uses the example of Guatemalan history to analyze the American media's approach to international stories. Judy Jackson shows a film about human rights violations in Brazil. Panelist discussion and audience questions examine television journalism, veterans' affairs, consumer behavior, and paranoia.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#4: United States -- Relations -- Former communist countries
description#1: Moderated by Susan Barney Jones. The panel discusses American foreign policy after the Cold War. Richard Dennis Baum discusses the end of the adversarial relationship between communism and liberalism, but argues that other conflicts will take its place. Julie Anne Johnson further illustrates the American relationship to the Soviet Union, and anticipates a difficult post-Cold War transition for the intelligence community. Richard Farson argues that the United States will be able to transition more of its resources into domestic development. Molly Ivins examines potential domestic and international conflicts, large and small. Audience questions cover the military-industrial complex, the war on drugs, and international aid organizations.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The First Amendment: Right to Speak or the Press of America's Right to Know
subject#2: Freedom of the press -- United States
description#1: Moderated by Michael Tracy. The panel explores the relationship between the First Amendment and the Press. Richard Aregood discusses the historical roots of freedom of speech and describes attempts to limit speech throughout the history of the United States. Jonathan Kwitny argues that the concentrated ownership of the media has resulted in a restricted flow of information; he provides several personal anecdotes of media corruption. Simon Hoggart discusses how newspapers cater to their audience, claiming there is a lack of reporting on atrocities in the world because Americans do not want to read sad news. Gene McDaniel emphasizes the fact that freedom of speech belongs to citizens and not just the press. He maintains that we have to fight for our right for freedom of speech as well as our right to know what is going on in the world.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Roderic Park. Molly Ivins presents a lecture on the state of the United States. She discusses the 1996 presidential election, summarizing the Republican candidates and their unique strengths and weaknesses. Ivins analyzes corruption in the American political system, and explores the growing dissatisfaction with the two-party system. She challenges cynicism about government, and encourages citizens to consider their own political responsibility. The lecture ranges to the implications of the Information Age on modern society and the role of satire in political commentary. Audience questions cover corporate politics, American media, and the war on drugs.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by William Wei. The panel discusses affirmative action. Philip Hart relates a personal story to illustrate how affirmative action should function. Nancy Ramsey urges a data-driven approach to the affirmative action debate. Linda Gorman argues against government-mandated affirmative action because free markets tend to eliminate discrimination. Molly Ivins counters that perfect meritocracies do not exist, and that affirmative action is necessary to prevent discrimination. Audience questions cover specific court cases, different types of discrimination, and practical considerations.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Men are from Venus, Women are from Mars
description#1: Moderated by Sharon Conlin. The panel discusses communication difficulties between men and women. Bill Weeden summarizes John Gray's Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus and argues that men and women communicate differently. Sally Fay agrees that women are different, but is concerned that these differences are used by society against women. Molly Ivins examines the historical oppression of women, and argues that stereotypes are a tool of oppression. Harvey Wasserman challenges these stereotypes and sees changing gender roles as a vision of the future. Audience questions focus on gender roles and homosexuality.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Death of Political Parties in America
description#1: Moderated by Doug Costain. The panel discusses the state of political parties in America. Nancy Ramsey covers the evolution of political parties and the emergence of new political parties. Jurek Martin compares the Anglo-Saxon and European political models, and concludes that the American political party system is still strong. Molly Ivins summarizes current Texas political events to demonstrate public dissatisfaction with the political establishment. The panel analyzes open primaries and women voters. Audience questions cover third parties, campaign finance reform, and the religious right.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Welfare Reform: What Can be Done? What Should be Done?
description#1: Moderated by Susan Purdy . David Kopel and Molly Ivins debate the topic of welfare reform. Kopel argues that single parent homes are a major predictor of violent crime and other social problems. He connects illegitimate children to the American welfare system, and argues that welfare reform must address this problem. Ivins disputes the statistical basis of Kopel's argument, argues that Kopel has overstated the problem, and identifies several other factors causing the rise in single parent homes. Ivins also proposes welfare reform based on an increase in social services. Audience questions cover personal responsibility, the minimum wage, public schools, and health care.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Can Big Business Save the Environment?
description#1: Moderated by Phil Deloria. The panel discusses the way businesses impact the environment, and how the public can influence big business. Mary Barley argues that consumers must encourage businesses to make environmentally conscious choices. Robert Repetto argues that citizens are more politically responsive than big business. Molly Ivins disagrees, arguing that businesses have much more money and power than private citizens. The panelists discuss subsidies, legal action, and money in politics. Audience questions cover environmental regulations, consumer choice, socioeconomic class, and the property rights movement.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jean Kim. In this session, Jonathan Broder and Molly Ivins discuss the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky scandal and its impact on feminism. Jonathan Broder frames the discussion by arguing that the scandal was not as serious as Watergate or the Iran-Contra scandal. Broder interviews Molly Ivins, asking questions that cover the various intersections between Monica Lewinsky and feminism in the public discourse. Ivins compares and contrasts different political scandals, pointing out hypocritical responses. The discussion also covers various legal actions taken against the Clinton administration. Audience questions cover historical and legal precedents, the media's role, and Hillary Clinton.Moderated by William Scanlon. ++++++++++++++

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Laurie Van Horn. The panel discusses the current state of American media in the late 1990s. Michael Elliott traces the positive changes in American media, specifically its integrated approach to international journalism. Molly Ivins disagrees with Elliott and identifies various failures of the media, including irresponsible fact-checking and poor subject selection. Patricia Ellis agrees with Ivins that the media is indefensible, especially as media outlets consolidate. Joseph Mehan points out that journalists have begun criticizing their own profession more fully. David Finkel uses a personal anecdote to illustrate the fallibility of the media. Audience questions cover endowed newspapers, political journalism, and media criticism.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Stuart Takeuchi. The panel discusses state governance in the United States. Molly Ivins argues that returning power to state governments risks corruption and unfunded mandates. Eric Sterling stresses the importance of an independent judiciary and an organized populace in regulating state government and correcting its mistakes. Tom Potter makes the case for citizen involvement in government at the local and state level. Panel discussion covers the intersection between states' rights and civil rights. Audience questions cover property rights movements, mass transit, campaign finance reform, labor unions, and the death penalty.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Mommy, Where Do Values Come From?
description#1: Moderated by Christine Denning. The panelists discuss personal and social values. Jory Agate asks the audience what their values are, before exhorting them to encourage society to reflect these values. Tom Minnery defines values as that which helps an individual decide what to do in difficult situations. Molly Ivins examines the political debate over family values, arguing that not all democratic values are privileged equally. During discussion, the panel debates the role of religious values in American society. Audience questions lead to discussions about homosexuality, religion, and personal responsibility.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Brits Look at the Yanks
subject#1: United States -- Foreign public opinion, British
description#1: Moderated by Kent Zimmerman . Molly Ivins interviews British panelists, soliciting opinions on political and social questions. Early topics include Ireland, speech patterns, and imperialism. Special attention is given to the historical relationship between the United States and the United Kingdom. The panelists strike a lighter note when they compare British and American wine, food, and humor. Coming from several different regions, the panelists compare and discuss accents. A final discussion compares violence in America and England. Audience questions cover the death of Princess Diana, anti-Americanism, and American Anglophilia.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Did Reagan Win the Cold War?
description#1: Moderated by Bob Greenlee. The panelists discuss the end of the Cold War and its consequences. Kirsten Amundsen credits several other leaders for the end of the Cold War, including Harry Truman. Felix Rodriguez argues that Reagan's policies increased military spending, and led to the fall of the Soviet Union. Molly Ivins points out that the Cold War lasted forty years, and no single world leader deserves full credit. Richard Aregood disputes that increased military spending was beneficial to the United States. During discussion, the panelists define multiple factors that eased the conflict. Audience questions cover Mikhail Gorbachev, other American presidents, and the role of the media.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Bruce Henderson. The panel discusses the 2000 American presidential election, and related issues like campaign finance reform and journalism. Mark Hertsgaard begins by arguing that the public discourse in American politics has degenerated over several decades. He links this degeneration to the culture in journalism that has devalued and effectively censored important stories. Molly Ivins continues the discussion by relating her experience covering the 2000 presidential election, including her thoughts on political reform. Dan Odescalchi shares Ivins' optimism that reform is probable, but expresses skepticism about campaign finance reform specifically. Richard Aregood laments the decline of responsible news reporting, especially in the realm of politics.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: How to be Cheerful about the American Political System...Anyway
description#1: Moderated by Richard Byyny. Molly Ivins begins her speech about the American political system by discussing President George W. Bush. Her speech continues by touching on money in politics, corruption, and a general sense that the American public's interest in democracy is waning. However, Ivins strikes an optimistic note, citing campaign finance reform legislation. She argues that the American populace is affected by the political system in ways that they do not always recognize, and encourages more people to become politically active. Audience questions cover Texas politics, Ann Richards, and the electoral college.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Cathy Comstock. The panel approaches the question posed by the title of the panel. Sean Kelly is uncomfortable with the title, and suggests that American voting systems may be more stupid than people. Dan Odescalchi argues that people in America have a stake in their government and tend to vote rationally. Simon Hoggart facetiously proposes an elitist scenario resulting in corporations voting in American elections. Joan Higman Davies makes an argument for proportional representation, and Molly Ivins makes a populist argument. During the audience question period, the panelists discuss voting patterns, the electoral college, education, and election strategy.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why Dubya Could Make a Great President
description#1: Moderated by Kathy Howe. Shortly after George W. Bush's inauguration, the speakers ironically make the case that Bush could make a great president. Topics include Bush's economic, education, and foreign policy. The question and answer period takes a slightly more serious tone, as the panel discusses Bush's Texas political career, family, Cabinet appointments, environmental record, and potential judicial nominees.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Laurie McNown. The panel discusses increasing polarization in the American legislature. Michael Franc outlines the legislative strategies employed by the Republican Party in the House of Representatives, which rely on alignment between partisanship and ideology. Molly Ivins decries pork-barrel politics and campaign financing. Tim Wirth attempts to understand Congress in 2003 by tracing the institution's history from the 1960s to the 2000s, concluding that legislative power is becoming centralized. Panel discussion focuses on the conservative Republican approach, while the question and answer session covers health care, money in politics, and potential solutions.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Don't Despair, America is Still Out There
description#1: Moderated by Richard Byyny. Using wit and satire, Molly Ivins addresses the American political landscape in the early 2000s. She explains her concern over the direction of the country, particularly with money in politics. However, Ivins cites anecdotal evidence from her journalistic career to argue that American people are extraordinarily resilient. She concludes her remarks by encouraging the audience to maintain a sense of humor while fighting for freedom. During the audience question period, Ivins covers topics like campaign finance reform, 21st century media, and the military conflict in Iraq.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why Conservative Pundits Are So Mean
description#1: Moderated by Christopher Brauchli. The panel discusses the American conservative approach to politics. Jurek Martin argues that conservatives engage in a political approach based on hate and lies. Daniel Odescalchi disagrees with the premise of the panel, making the case that conservative pundits are usually wrongly accused of meanness when they use humor. Molly Ivins argues that she is less concerned with unkind rhetoric than with policies that hurt people. Michael Franc explores the media landscape in the 20th century, concluding that as organizations compete for ratings they often become mean-spirited. Panel discussion and audience questions attempt to define conservatism and the possibility for civility in political discourse.

description#1: Moderated by Simon Hoggart. The panel takes the form of a news quiz game based on Simon Hoggart's British television show. Questions cover the Iraq war, popular culture, and current political events. The panelists use the questions as an opportunity for satire and political humor, telling jokes and creating fake movie titles based on the Bush administration and the Iraq war.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Health Care Delivery Systems: Market or Government Control
description#1: Moderated by Carla King. The panel discusses health care in America. Terry McNally examines the concept of holistic health maintenance, and how it relates to potential health care alternatives. Michael Franc compares different free market options and makes the case for consumer choice. Ruth Oratz argues that American health care is fractured and provides different levels of service to different people in an arbitrary way. Molly Ivins focuses on the costs incurred by consumers and hospitals, arguing that a single-payer system would be most effective at reducing these costs. The audience question and answer period covers administrative costs in health care, alternative medicine, and political will.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series X: Is Art Saying Anything to Anyone
description#1: Moderated by Curt Zimansky. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movies made in mid-1960s have no meaning and no paraphrasable content. Ebert then talks about how people read novels to find out how it ends. Also, Ebert provides two ways in which a director deals with their ideas. Steven A. Linn talks about why people tend to put film in a category separate from other art forms. Larry Horton explains why movies are the only art form where one can sit down with anybody and get an honest response.

titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by John Loeffler. Robert B. Bathurst starts by talking about how mutual security is a state of mind and a psychological perception of threat. Bathurst also mentions how power is about how well we perceive a threat. Thomas A. Halsted talks about nuclear weapon posture as another aspect to US military policy towards Europe. Halsted questions how nuclear weapon should be used towards our enemies and how it will enhance our European allies. William Wilberforce briefly states how both countries must have equal respect for the vital interest of both sides.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series II: What the Declaration of Independence does not Mention: A Right to Property
description#1: Moderated by Patricia B. Trainer. Roger Ebert begins by talking about why he doesn't agree with the public having the right to know everything. David C. Butterfield points out a few factors regarding the private life of a public person. Butterfield explains why in most cases people are victims of self censorship. Butterfield then questions where the line is drawn in what is legitimately private in the life of a public person. Patricia O'Brien talks about how people are most interested in knowing the sex lives of public people.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Society: Idealistic Goals Versus Human Rights
titleSeries#1: Series VIII: Created Equal but Everywhere Unequal
description#1: Moderated by Robert M. Hunter. The panel begins with the audience asking the panelists questions. Members of the audience ask questions to know more about the purpose of the panel, and also questions if things like integrity and honesty are considered old fashioned. Then a discussion between the panelists and audience regarding Peter Principle arise. Further questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: @00:04 Host introduces speaker @1:34 Fairlie begins @51:21 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by James N. Corbridge. The speaker discusses the differences between the U.S. and Europe from the 18th to 20th centuries, using examples of clothing, language, beliefs, and various roles between Europe and this 'free country'. America exerts its influence in the supermarket (as a symbol of consumer society), as well as in clothing, mass production, and automobiles. These concepts are accompanied by ideas for which the young are responsible, such as influencing speech throughout the world and triggering liberation movements worldwide. Americans tend to reduce society to pieces to see how it works, in the belief that we can rebuild and reshape society.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Kenneth R. Hammond. Steven A. Linn begins by talking about a few murders that have occurred. Roger Ebert talks about terrorism by the gross and states that it is both an individual and institutional thing. Ebert then discusses extremist movements in the world. Larry Horton talks about articles released after the Kennedy assassination. Edwin Casebeer explains why he thinks of terrorism as a political act. Casebeer then states how mass murder terrorizes people, but is not necessarily an act of terrorists. Christopher Cory discusses the safety valve theory of surrogate violence. Cory questions if there are societies with less than greater degrees of violence.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by Norman A. Hilmar. Robert B. Bathurst begins by talking about what is wrong with military war machine as a representation of itself and society, and how it could be fixed. Bathurst compares the similarity of the military system between the United States and the Soviet Union. Franklin talks about how the United States government does have a global strategy. Then, Franklin mentions the Vietnam War, and the reasoning behind why the United States lost. Gennady I. Fedosov talks about Bathurst's comparison between the United States and Soviet Union more in depth. Fedosov also describes the complexity of the problem the two nations face regarding disarmament.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series V: The Mythology of the American Experience
description#1: Moderated by Ronald C. Billingsley. Ray L. Hart begins by talking about why death has been an un-American activity and why it is now becoming an American activity. Edwin Casebeer states how the horror of death is the horror of existing in hell. Casebeer then talks about love and death. Phillip K. Bock tries to relate the subject of the panel with anthropology. Brock explains how the feeling about death in the American society is deeply repressed. Jack Forem states how talking about death is pointless because it is inevitable. Forem ends the panel by telling people to live life as fully as possible.

description#1: @00:22 Host introduces speaker @5:10 Fiedler begins @50:32 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Frederick P. Theime. He speaks of the counterculture as it split into political and cultural revolutions. The American "cultural revolution" since the mid-1950s was associated with black emancipation, but has also produced broader change throughout American popular culture. The nation has changed in human rights, media, politics, relationships, and even in how we portray our thoughts. We all experience many aspects of the culture, and we all differ from our past generations. With different kinds of people comes a revolution.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Alice Reich. Hayden White begins by talking about how violence is regarded as a necessary condition for the transformation of society. White explains why violence in the media is socially less revolutionary than pornography. Lonny Myers explains what violence does to people and morality in terms of the media. Roger Ebert talks about the esthetics of violence and the ethical nature of violent content in the media. Ebert then answers a question on why violence is more cinematic than sex. Melvin Howards talks about how there can be two types of violence, the verbal and the nonverbal type.

description#1: @00:00:01 Introduction of panelists @00:02:35 Richard Holbrooke talks @00:12:04 Holbrooke ends @00:13:02 Yukio Satoh talks @00:22:42 Satoh ends @00:23:00 Hebert Scoville talks @00:30:06 Scoville ends @00:30:25 Vladamir Tuminov begins @00:44:33 Tuminov end
description#2: Richard Holbrooke examines the different approaches to negotiations with specific reference to Vietnam, and his direct association with negotiations in Paris for the first year and a half. He talks of his personal experience, and then shares general observations. Discusses the philosophies of U.S. military officials in negotiations. Yukio Satoh explores Japanese foreign policy, as a member of Japanese Foreign Servic -- discussing its weak points, peace maintenance, and Japan's dependency on U.S. military power for security of Japan and its defenses. Herbert Scoville discusses a different approach to negotiations with specific regards to arms control. Vladamir Tuminov responds to other panelists, discusses chain of foreign policy, speech writing and foreign policy, gap between rich and poor countries. Chairman Thad Tecza presiding.

description#1: @00:04 John Lawler introduces speaker @2:18 Miller begins @58:22 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by John Lawler (substituting for Robert A. Aldrich). The speaker describes a new 'ism': ageism, in which young people are unfairly judged and sentenced to penal institutions. He calls for correctional reforms with quick and massive changes, without waiting. He describes reform attempts in Massachusetts, before their juvenile institutions were closed. The speaker provides numerous examples of the abuses in programs at their "training" schools. Miller feels that alternatives for youngsters should engage and educate them, and he predicts that conventional institutions will only create more violence and insanity.

titleSeries#1: Series XIV: Arms and the Man
description#1: Moderated by Rodger Padget. Peter Mayors begins by stating that people no longer have a positive faith in defensive armament or in pacifism as a positive force. Molse discusses why getting rid of all armed forces doesn't provide a utopian world. Molse talks about how there won't be state of peace unless everybody wants it. Rivers discusses how a whole system of relationship within society depends on exploited relationships. River also talks about his stay in Angola and states that the people in Angola are united because of the presence of an external oppressor. River ends the panel by questioning if the people would still be united if there was no external oppressor.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Thomas D. Bird. H. Bruce Franklin begins by talking about the two most violent events in human history caused by the United States. Franklin suggests that in order to deal with violence historically, one has to look at the root causes of violence that took place within a society. Russell Baker talks about how acts of terror are instantly communicated with all worlds through the media. H. Bruce Franklin talks about terrorism as a phenomenon in the 20th century. Franklin states that the most sensationalized acts of terrorism are from the acts committed by the state.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Violence is Sex; Sex is Violence
description#1: Moderated by Philippe Almeras. Edwin Casebeer begins by talking about the similarities of violence and sex. Casebeer then talks about why death and love doesn't have a lot to do with sex and violence. Larry Horton talks about the issues of civil liberty in the media. Horton states his opinion on why problems of violence are much more troubling than problems of sex in film. Jane Howard explains why people confuse violence with strength. Roger Ebert talks about violence and sex in movies, and explains why violence is more cinematic than sex.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Phyllis Kenevan. John Newhouse begins by talking about what fourth world really means. Newhouse discusses the attitude of both the supplier and recipient countries of arms weapon. Christopher J. Makins talks about the key arguments regarding questions of leverage and the "if I don't, someone else will" argument that Newhouse has mentioned earlier. William L. Eagleton briefly explains why countries want arms in the first place. Ovidia Soffer discusses some concrete examples regarding the problems the other three panelists previously mentioned.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Theo Volsky, Jr. John Newhouse begins by talking about the détente occurring between the United States and the Soviet Union. Newhouse states that the United States and Soviet forces are hard to compare because they are so different. Then, Newhouse advises that in order to achieve the stability that the two nations need, the number of strategic weapons has to be limited and the process of increasing the destructive potential of weapons has to be restrained. Newhouse ends by saying that SALT should be seen as steps of progress which will lead to greater stability.

titleSeries#1: Series XI: The Changing Understanding of What is Human and What is Natural in Human Nature
description#1: Moderated by Payson D. Sheets. Jack Forem begins by suggesting the audience to look at two words that seems to be implied in the title: wholeness and holiness. Forem then talks about how any individual who lives in the wholeness of life would be a person capable of being called holy. Jane Howard talks about her experiences investing different approaches toward holiness and wholeness. Roger Ebert also talks about his experience regarding his first-hand contact with two representatives in the human potential movement. Jack Forem ends the panel by talking about movements and followers.

description#1: Moderated by Virgil F. Grillo. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how form is the way a director imposes their style. Ebert states two things that make movies an art: director's control over space and control over time. Lindsay Dean talks about how moving images are able to recreate the posture and emotional intensity of sculpture. Peter M. Mayer talks about how American movies are the most important movies made because of the influence of American economy, images, and lifestyle. Polly Toynbee talks about things film can't do and expresses her thoughts on films and novels.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Earl Sampson. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movie actors are perceived as fantasies in the 1930s and 1940s. Ebert states why movie actors give us role models and why movies are the greatest voyeuristic, escapist art form of all time. Leslie Kopit talks about how illusions in movies help people come to a deeper truth and help make certain roles become possible. Richard W. B. Lewis talks about superficial influences from actors. Lewis states that great movies are a clarification of life, then questions why there aren't there more great movies. Inge Schneier Hoffmann talks about heroes and anti-heroes in movies in the last few decades.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Betram Morris. Flora Natapoff begins by talking about the subject of nostalgia in terms of pictures. Roger Ebert talks about nostalgic movies and also talks about why nostalgia is a constant motif in advertising. Ebert answers yes and no to the question, is nostalgia debilitating. Peter Michael Mayer talks about nostalgia as an issue in American life. Mayer specifies one area in which nostalgia is always debilitating. Shepherd Brooks talks about the definition of nostalgia. Arthur Kopit explains why nostalgia is not a search for pain, but rather a search for an alternate dream life.

description#1: @00:08 host introduces speaker @5:14 Stringfellow begins @56:29 Stringfellow ends / open for audience discussion @1:12:57 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by John R. Carnes. The speaker discusses the prevalence of espionage and surveillance in our Capital. He sees the entanglement of public relations (as a merchandising technique) with politics to be one of the main concerns in the Watergate scandal. The speaker emphasizes that current legal ethics demonstrate the relationship of authority and law. He describes this as the 'Nixonian' view, that the acts of coercive authority are the law. He specifies that lawless authority has especially affected American Indians and American blacks. Coercion arises not only from local police or judicial authorities, but is also a principal tool of the Pentagon in the prosecution of illegal war. Increase in lawless authority coincides with growth in technology and the momentum for social change.

description#1: Moderated by Edward P. Nolan. John Newhouse begins by talking about how SALT is a way in generating some restraint in the strategic arms competition. Newhouse states that SALT would not be possible if both sides were not in some degree of parody. Makins briefly mentions the importance of understanding what SALT really is. Engelbert Washietl emphasizes another aspect  European Security Conference  of the whole problem. Dolf Doge ends the panel by stating how the psychology of the United States has built up on the image of seeing progress toward the possibility of ending arms race.

title#1: The Whore with the Heart of Gold
titleSeries#1: Series V: The Mythology of the American Experience
description#1: Moderated by Curt R. Zimansky. Jennifer James begins by defining prostitution in terms of the American society. James explains four main aspects of prostitution: cash, promiscuity, relationship, and subtlety. James also talks about the appropriate use of criminal law. Timothy L. Findley talks about the differences between prostitution and whoring, professionalism and non-professionalism. Nat Lehrman talks about how there should be no arrests for crimes without victims. Lehrman also comments on James's definition of promiscuity with another definition. Roger Ebert talks about legalization of prostitution and questions James if she opposes prostitution all together.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Thomas Findley discusses his relationship with Huey Newton as a reporter. He describes how both the Black Panther Party uses the media to create awareness for the movement, and in turn, they are misrepresented in the media. Discusses media's role in creating a "rock star" image for Newton. Expresses a frustration on behalf of reporters' inability to challenge conservative national media, specifically its editors and publishers. Henry Fairlie points out that the role of a journalist is to question those who seek power. Patricia Karvall discusses how the media supports the message. Discusses self-criticism among the press. Last speaker discusses people as transmitters of "symbolic codes." Chairman Thomas D. Bird presiding.

description#1: Moderated by John Dunn. Marcus Cohn begins by talking about how the problem of pornography is related to the past. Cohn points out a few concerns in newspapers/magazines regarding pornography. Roger Ebert talks about how pornography is not cinematic but violence is. Ebert explains that pornography of violence and pornography of sex are related in the sense that they provide jolts, chills, or thrills to the audience watching it. Cosmo Campoli talks about taking sex to a high spiritual state where women are more like a temple rather than something that is disgraced.

description#1: Moderated by Andree Kail. Pepper Schwartz begins by talking about body image and briefly defines what body image is. Shepherd Brooks explains why popular images are not what people should be like or aspire to be, and suggests people to be themselves and to be comfortable with it. Robert Ebert talks about bodies and movies. Ebert states that a story in a movie doesn't mean anything, and that it comes down to body language. Robert Irwin talks about how there is more than one definition in art. Irwin states why art is not an act of either communication or an attempt to inform.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#2: Soviet Union. Treaties, etc. United States, 1972 May 26 (SALT)
description#1: Moderated by Joseph Lazar. Robert B. Bathurst begins by stating that the United States and the Soviet Union are to a degree neutralized. Bathurst explains what the Soviet Union is doing with their conventional forces. Bathurst ends by questioning whether the United States is going to help countries to be independent within their nuclear umbrella and to provide psychological strength. Questions from the audience follow.

description#1: Moderated by H. Leedom Lefferts, Jr.. William McPherson begins by talking about a movie, The Exorcist. McPherson explains that the popularity of the movie and novel means something; indicates a reaction against idealism. Christopher Cory talks about how the popularity of the exorcist is an expression of compassion fatigue. Edwin Casebeer then explains the variation of a quote and discusses whether people are pondering the devil as a reality. Casebeer states that people are turning towards a myth to be horrified because of the activity of rationalists.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Paul Levitt. Arthur Kopit begins by talking about an aspect of nostalgia and states two types of nostalgia: definition of the word and assumption of the habits of another era. Kopit then provides a list of things that will probably disappear and be nostalgic for. Richard W. B. Lewis talks about the definition of nostalgia, which he defines as homesickness. Inger Schneier Hoffmann talks about how nostalgia is not just nostalgia for the past, losses, or place, but a longing for a more perfect state. Then a discussion about nostalgia between the panelists begins, followed by questions from the audience.

description#2: [Reportedly] moderated by James Corbridge [introduced by un-named Latina student]. The speaker [David Barthene, substituting for Hortensia B. Viuda de Allende] describes Chile's struggle for a peaceful transition to a just society. Salvador Allende, the president of Chile, used various tactics to pursue agrarian reforms, eradication of unemployment, and economic improvement by curbing the flow of Chilean wealth to developed nations. Allende presented socialism as a nonviolent alternative to colonialism and imperialism. However, the military opposition still controlled most events in Chile. In response, the speaker claims that the Chilean people fought for liberation around the world and for justice in their homeland.

titleSeries#1: Series X: Is Art Saying Anything to Anyone
description#1: Moderated by Harold D. Kelling. William McPherson begins by making some distinctions regarding the tyranny of the critics by talking about current works, not works of the past. McPherson also makes another distinction about critics and reviewers, and states that he is a reviewer. Leslie Kopit talks about a problem regarding critics and a problem regarding criticism. Kopit then states that critics are not necessarily experts. William Braden explains why there is adverse criticism by book reviewers and also explains how a book gets reviewed. Steven A. Linn shows the audience some slides of his own sculpture.

description#1: Moderated by Blaine E. Mercer. Grace Husted begins by talking about how the interpretation of age and sex is changing so rapidly that it's important to encompass it from a different point of view. Husted talks about sex in terms of gender. Robert Ebert argues how Grace Husted's speech has anything to do with the topic of the panel. Ebert states that regarding politics of sex, a woman has a greater handicap in being elected president than a black man because women aren't trusted by either men or women. Henry Fairlie states his difficulty regarding women's liberation and states that women's liberation doesn't define common humanity.

description#1: Moderated by Thomas Blau. Herbert Scoville begins by talking about two agreements on strategic arms limitation such as the ABM Treaty. Then, Scoville briefly talks about mutual balance force reduction and advices not to worry about the balance but rather about the mutual force reduction. Farangis De Munoz blames the military for creating the Vietnam situation and states that the military services have been running the country for a long time. Munoz questions why the military mind is dominated in many parts of the world. Stanley Reed ends the panel by stating that arms control agreement can be accomplished.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Continuity and Discontinuity in Russian and Marxist Thought
subject#2: Communism and Christianity -- Soviet Union -- History
description#1: Moderated by Norman Michaels. The speakers discuss the traditions of 20th century Russian history, the Marxist party and the Bolsheviks. The Marxists (led by Lenin) proposed a rational but utopian ideal. In pre-Soviet Russian religion, there was no individual salvation; instead, people could be saved only in a community. Similarly, the Russian revolution can be best viewed through the attitude of the peasants. Eventually, the revolution favored the proletarian struggle and limited the liberty of the peasants. One speaker contends that all governmental measures in Soviet Russia strengthened centralized state power over wide areas, with a focus on national survival.

title#1: Deep Eye, Ear, Nose and Sore Throat
description#1: Moderated by Donald J. Unruh. Roger Ebert talks about how he thinks pornography can be therapy. Inge Schneier Hoffmann states how she has come into terms with certain issues concerning pornography. Hoffman explains that she believes art and pornography are incompatible. Pepper Schwartz talks about the basis of pornography. Schwartz then briefly talks about pornography in women and questions what is considered erotic. Michael Gold talks about how he thinks pornography in New York has gone out of hand.

description#1: Moderated by Robert M. Hunter. Robert J. Low begins by explaining what he thinks the panel is about. Low states that there are two elements regarding the panel: the right to know and the right of privacy. Low suggests that the issue lies on the right of the press to know what's going on in the counsel's government. Peter M. Mayer mentions that the issues back then were not the same as now; the issue didn't have to do with the press but rather deals with the right to know as a citizen. Mayer then briefly talks about the Army McCarthy Hearings.

description#1: Moderated by Barbara Jones. Samuel Rosenburg begins by talking about how there was a time where pornography had great emotional charge. Rosenburg states how pornography was once a private domain of masculine society and how pornography has now become devaluated because it's no longer private. Roger Ebert talks about how the 20th century drowned down pornography. Ebert explains how porn is a dying field and art. Grace Husted suggests that there is a cultural difference in ascetic and aesthetic directions. Grace talks about how different cultures have different value systems regarding pornography which one shouldn't damage.

description#1: Moderated by Forrest Williams. Marya Mannes begins by talking about how young audiences were laughing during a rape scene in the movie Clockwork Orange. Marya expresses her distaste in such a happy response to violence. Marya then states how frequent use of violence in films is a conscious rape against the sensibility of what's left in the audience. Robert Ebert agrees with Mannes regarding Clockwork Orange and briefly talks about violence in films and critics. Then a discussion between Mannes and Ebert starts with Mannes talking about how criticism isn't just confined to films. Mannes asks Ebert if French films use violence in the extent Americans do.

description#1: The speakers discuss how politics mixes with the notion of thespian with a criterion of our candidate must act depending on the prospective audience. A well qualified candidate must represent the nation, but given the equality of power in the government with massive staff workforce, the work is hardly authentic. Meaning, the media sets up an image and forces others to follow, but the speakers argue that people do know more than they are able to articulate. It's posited that candidates must be thespians in order to convey their ideas, and must take advantage of technology for mass communication.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Chessman Case and Capital Punishment
description#1: The speaker gives a brief history of Chessman's life. With a disabled mother and living in poverty, he resorted to burglary and car theft. Marrying in 1940, he divorced a year later and was convicted in 1941 of robbery and assault. In jail he spent his time teaching subjects and debating, only to be caught in 1947 as the red-light bandit, so he was then trialed for 18 charges. This case became a legal-limbo for Chessman who had 8 executions spared out of 9. Thus in this panel capital punishment and abolishment are discussed, including statistics on the pros and cons of the death penalty. Speakers discuss the importance of the deterrent effect, rather than executions.

titleSeries#1: Series X: Sex in the Afternoon
description#1: Moderated by Christopher R. Brauchli. Roger Ebert summarizes the findings of the President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography. Leonard Gross discusses the Swedish film, I Am Curious (Yellow), and how it exemplifies the idea of releasing frustration through art. Nicholas Von Hoffman argues that pornography has a right to exist and that the purported societal effects that it causes have been blown out of proportion. Liz Carpenter tells various anecdotes and believes that pornography is a form of "pollution."

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Arms Race: Their View and Ours
description#1: Moderated by Patrick Jobes. Robert Vincent Daniels begins by giving background on attempts to control arms and arms limitation efforts. Daniels briefly talks about the struggles of nuclear and conventional agreement between America and Russia. Club Bateau states that the best solution for disarmament would be to destroy/block not only the bombs, but also the means of delivery. Walter H. Pincus discusses his views towards arms race by saying that the United States approach to disarmament is more of a domestic consideration than an international consideration. Pincus states that any agreement is going to involve chance, and a lack in arms control agreement will only cause a continuation of the arms race.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Cold War and the Drift to the Garrison State
description#1: Moderated by Eugene Wilson, Vice President of the University. The speaker, New York journalist Norman Thomas, argues the pros of the Socialist party in a culture and society torn by opposing political perspectives. Speaker highlights issues surrounding the bipartisan system, later comparing and contrasting the Socialist party against the Democratic and Republican parties. Noting the downfalls of a two party system, Speaker discusses the need for a 3rd party to create a balance between polarizing perspectives. Speaker concludes by discussing the benefits of a socialized culture and government as opposed to one which has been imbued by political and fiscal ideologies.

description#2: Moderated by Robert B. Jacobs. Mulford Q. Sibley discusses the strengths and inadequacies of the United Nations. Grover Rich speaks on the nature of politics to understand how the UN can be more useful. He defines politics and political power as the ability to coerce. Sibley challenges Rich on the topic of coercion. Chawla explains that the U.N has become necessary as a means to diffuse international conflict. Brian Urquhart also believes the U.N is necessary because of its numerous benefits and equalizing role for all countries. Tad Krauze discusses the issue of the UN in terms of the individual and its psychological necessity. Noel Parrish questions the use of force in the United Nations.

description#1: Moderated by E. A. M. Gendreau. Jiri Nehevajsa introduces the topic, then all panelists debate with each other about the extent to which the U.S. government should emphasize scientific or military programs in space. All speakers, some social scientists some military officials, give their opinions on space warfare and what it might mean to "control space". The cold war and role of Russia in space exploration is particularly discussed. The panelists also consider pros and cons of developing military versus scientific space programs. Questions from the audience follow.

title#1: Disarmanent Control and the Arms Agency
description#1: Moderated by Floyd Baskette. Roger Fisher begins by stating that arms control is important as long as people recognize what it can and cannot do. Fisher mentions how disarmament is controlled by agreement and adequate inspection. Then, Scott Payne begins talking about the reasons behind inspection and agreement, and the complexity behind disarmament. Payne also states the benefits of disarmament by mentioning some treaties. Norman I. Gelman begins by talking about the politics behind disarmament and the history of failure of disarmament as a policy. Gelman ends by agreeing with Payne saying that the only way to approach disarmament is through a peace approach.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series X: Sex in the Afternoon
description#1: Moderated by David A. Breternitz. Roger Ebert describes the evolution of movies in terms of the average viewer, the types of movies, the film rating system, types of X-rated films, and violence in movies. Kay L. Corbett asks why American society is so obsessed with sex and if the panelists have ever seen a "really beautiful erotic film." Michael Wadleigh describes the type of people on rating commissions, the process of rating Woodstock, and censorship of Woodstock in other countries. Sam Rosenberg argues that a similar movement has already occurred in literature and that, in each time period, sex was used as a socio-political tool.

description#1: The possession and operation of atomic weapons are discussed by the speakers. There are currently three countries with nuclear programs: the United States, Britain, and Russia. Only public opinion will raise the pressure to ban nuclear tests and dissuade other nations from developing nuclear weapons of their own. The task is for these three active countries with the knowledge and background to reduce nuclear capacity and eventually lead to disarmament.
