identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The External Relations of the People's Republic of China
description#1: @00:05 host introduces speaker @3:03 Mehta begins @47:20 Mehta ends / open to discussion and questions @55:43 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Stanislaw Ulam. The speaker claims that past judgments of China have erroneously focused on a drift between the Soviet Union and China. He states that faulty views of China emphasize a Maoist variant of Marxism, interested only in its own security. He suggests that China seeks links between her traditions and her new revolutionary ideologies; thus other nations should clarify their policies toward China. Her policies seem to be based on solidarity with the developing world, growth of external trade, securing governmental controls, the drive to industrialize, and the rubrics of Marxism and Leninism. China's relations appear pragmatic, and its interests in the world should not be dismissed.

description#1: @1:37 Ebert begins @14:00 Fairlie begins @20:00 Rosenberg begins @35:54 panel discussion @1:03:19 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Kerry Pataki. The panel discusses the various forms of X-rated films, including "stag films", "adult" films, and "skin flicks", which are rated X by the MPAA. The Immoral Mr. Teas (1959) was the first skin-flick in the American repertoire. The discussion attempts to describe the function of these films, their purpose, and the dangers they might present to American society. Speakers believe that these films tend to lack good filmmaking. These experiences matter especially to young adults, whose profound curiosity for the naked body renders the films irresistible. However, the speakers all agree that the X-rated film will eventually self-destruct because after viewing it, two human beings still have to communicate with each other, with or without sex.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series VI: The Nixonization of the Nation
description#1: @00:14 host introduces panel @4:16 Midgley begins @22:49 Herzstein begins @39:15 Fairlie begins @46:10 Fairlie ends / questions from the floor @1:38:14 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Ray Cuzzort. [Two years before 5 men try to break into offices of the Democratic National Committee at the Watergate hotel], the speakers describe the Nixon administration either as 'Watergate' or 'waterlog'. Their usage varies, but one speaker claims that the hotel symbolizes problems of political and social life in the U.S. The actions of Nixon and his cabinet are discussed and compared to those of previous presidents. One speaker argues that Nixon's administration was effective, in that it senses the aspirations of the American people and appeals to their energies to translate them into effective programs.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Edward A. Amstutz. Alan V. Washburn begins speaking about the efforts of disarmament that has been going and are going on, ranging from broadest to narrowest. Washburn briefly talks about the Test Ban Treaty, Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, Multiple Independently Targetable Reentry Vehicle (MIRV), chemical and biological warfare, and arms transfer. He states that there is an inverse correlation between the effectiveness and realism of effort, and the success in the real world. Then, Washburn's colleagues briefly give their opinion about how efforts towards disarmament are negligible.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#3: Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund
description#1: Moderated by Ricardo Moya. The speakers discuss the richness of the Chicano culture -- its language, traditions, and people. Speeches highlight Chicano attempts to participate in government, to improve education and equal opportunities for young adults, and to attain appointments to judicial positions. The main speaker, Calleros, claims that the term 'harvest of shame' evokes the hard work and inequality Chicanos have endured: changes in language, the Mexican territories lost to the U.S. in 1848, and other injustices inflicted upon Chicanos.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Norman J. Michaels. William Simon states that the relationship between the mainstream and the underground has become less distinct over time since the mainstream is able to incorporate the underground faster and the underground has become more homogenous. Stanley Forster Reed argues that free press does not exist in America because it derives too much funding from various corporations. The panelists discuss the impossibility of objectivity in reporting and technology in the counterculture.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Dr. Bruner states that western culture is faced with a crisis of values and he argues that foreign policies reflect our values. He explains the crisis in the nature of myths, ideals of society, the nature of the universe, and man; also, explaining the relation of myths to human condition and the intellectual community, in search for identity. Economic well being and adjusted happiness must be equal among strong and weak nations, which in turn increases communication for the myth of self. Bruner states that we must be ready to look at revolutionary challenge in creating conceptions of man and nature through all aspects of economic and political power.

description#1: Moderated by Chris Burns. William H. Blanchard begins talking about two kinds of pressures  honesty and seriousness  offered by negotiators in the American culture. Then, Blanchard asks the audience what they think of him. Peter I. Markov begins speaking by stating his opinion towards serious negotiations. Markov states that negotiations not taken seriously fail and he ends his speech by saying both countries will benefit if both sides are sincere and serious. Michael S. March presents numerical data on the United States government budget since the 1950s. Lastly, an unidentified speaker briefly suggests that United States negotiators should take a more realistic view point.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Military Establishment: Its Impact on American Society
description#1: Moderated by William E. Briggs. Adam Yarmolinsky begins by talking about the relevance/irrelevance of the military establishment in the United States. He states that the size and pervasiveness of the American military establishment have tended to obscure the questions of its relevance. Yarmolinsky questions how something so big like the military can be relevant, and to what purpose. He also states his opinion that nonnuclear forces are relevant in some way to national security but are irrelevant to internal problems of other nations. Yarmolinsky ends his speech by exhorting the audience to broaden their views about what is really relevant to our national needs.

description#1: @00:08 George Truesdale introduces the CWA Session as a part of the program "Challenge To Thought" @00:58 Quigg Newton introduces Tom Mboya @03:35 Tom Mboya talks @54:28 Mboya ends @56:00 George Truesdale concludes the radio broadcast @58:55 tape ends
description#2: Tom Mboya speaks about Africa's problems and its future. He describes the forces striving to free Africa from colonial rule and establish a new order. He talks about the territorial boundaries that were established without respect to geographical divisions or ethnic groupings. He concluded by stating that all Africa asks of the United States is understanding that Africans have the same desires as the U.S. is willing to fight for. Panel chair Quigg Newton presiding.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#2: Nuclear weapons -- Economic aspects -- United States -- History -- 20th century.
description#1: Moderated by William G. MacDonald. Stanley Reed analyzes the economics behind the acquisition of nuclear weapons. Donald Michael mentions the benefits of establishing a weapon systems evaluation and who is involved in the process. Richard Fryklund argues that elected civilian officials should be in charge of what weapons system is used. Harvey Averch states that both informed government officials and civilians have a role to play in weapon systems evaluation (which he calls "systems analysis"). MacDonald defends the military by pointing out it is difficult to provide the public with accurate cost estimates for weapons systems when the majority of information is highly classified.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series XVII: Toys Men Play With
description#1: Moderated by Bruce F. Curtis. Edgard von Schmidt-Pauli discusses generals, the topic of nonproliferation and atomic energy, and the common tone created by military establishments. Jiri Nehnevajsa asks to what extent high military officers influence government policy and determine a country's fate. He also questions the power that generals have in ordering weapons and by extension war. Russell Baker focuses on the toys of war, including both the weapons and the gadgets used in combat. He discusses the necessity of eventual disarmament and the need to control the power of generals.

title#1: The Role of Smart Weapons in Non-Nuclear Forces
description#1: Moderated by Lloyd Weber. Philip Morrison begins by talking about how technology plays an important role in security issues. Morrison explains how large expenses in vehicles which remain extensive become more extensive. Raymond S. Sleeper talks about how warfare affects social conditions. Sleeper explains how social conditions developing around the world are within the people's influence. Sleeper then talks about model situations between the two conflicting systems. David Singer talks about how both the United States and Soviet Union are complex industrial societies with different kinds of interest groups.

title#1: United States Military Forces: Requirements for NATO
subject#2: United States -- Military policy -- Public opinion.
subject#3: United States -- Armed Forces -- Appropriations and expenditures
description#1: Moderated by Reuben Zubrow. Christopher J. Makins discusses the history of U.S. public opinion on U.S. military involvement in world affairs and gives his opinion on the current situation. Hans von Klutz explains the European view on NATO. Mr. Walker provides some statistics on U.S. and European forces. Ian Soutar discusses Soviet involvement in world affairs and the actions NATO has taken. Katherine L. Camp comments on the growth of the U.S. military budget and the cost of NATO to member countries. Raymond S. Sleeper compares the U.S. military force with that of the Soviet Union.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Mitzi M. Wertheim states that in every war, in which the United States has fought prior to the 20th century, women have seen combat. She gives the history of women in the services during the 20th century, noting the major turning points in policy during World War II and the change in attitudes during the 1960s and 1970s. She describes the current issues of women in the military, including pregnancy, promotion, and combat service. Chairman Dwayne C. Nuzum presiding.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Richard Schwarz. Each of the panelists introduces what they will talk about before returning to the stage. Weeden returns to gives a "personal history" that is meant to resemble an introduction at an AA meeting. Goodheart returns to go into more detail about her ex-husband's alcoholism, her experiences as a therapist, and the effects of having alcoholic parents. Ebert returns to describe what an AA meeting is like, how he became an alcoholic, how being an alcoholic affected his professional life, what it was like growing up in an alcoholic family, and how he became sober.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by J. Edward Murray. There are two common methods to avoid nuclear war: avoiding conventional wars and deterrence. Samuel T. Cohen believes the former is impossible since the U.S. would need to be ready to fight "Vietnam-type wars" at all times. He also states that deterrence may not work since the U.S. has no guarantee that their retaliatory forces would sufficiently cripple the Soviet Union. Cohen also mentions that containment is "a dangerous myth" and urges the U.S. to focus on defending itself instead. Cohen concludes with a personal anecdote about meeting various Catholic figures.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Fortieth Anniversary of the Atomic Bombing of Hiroshima
description#1: Moderated by Joseph Geiger. Michael B. Stoff begins by briefly explaining the city of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. He then talks about the effects of the bomb, "little boy" and "fat man", in detail. He presents numerical data on the deaths that occurred due to the bomb. Stoff then presents a historical melodrama in four acts  Act 1: The Decision to Build the Bomb, Act 2: The Decision to Use the Bomb, Act 3: The Decision to Keep the Atomic Secret, Act 4: Hiroshima and the Holocaust  to see how the bomb set the past and shaped the future.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Role of Sound Radio and Serious Writing
description#1: Moderated by Paul Danish. Laurie Taylor begins by talking about the decline in American radio drama and documentary. Taylor questions what has happened to the American radio. Maureen Buunyan talks about four areas where she has a connection with the radio. Buunyan also talks about her experience on television news and states that people who watch television are only watching and not listening. Lee Allen talks about a few observations on radio from a different aspect. Allen discusses the importance in radio outside the United States. Roger Ebert talks about how the radio could leave so much imagination and how sound create pictures in peoples mind.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: What I Want to do When I Grow Up
description#1: Moderated by Anne R. Higman. Peter Tauber begins by asking the audience if they think it's important to grow up. Tauber then answers by staying it's very important to grow up. Malcomlm Bradbury talks about how he would be a writer like James Joyce if he could grow up again. Fourth speaker talks about the world affair conference. Fourth speaker states that he wanted to be president when he was younger. Fourth speaker then jokingly announces his candidacy as the President of the United States and starts his speech. Questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Bob Watford. Leonard Feather begins by talking about how illiteracy can be defined in different ways. Feather then states different degrees of illiteracy. Claudio Spies talks about other forms of illiteracy such as insufficient reading. Spies discusses the irresponsibility of teachers and how the teaching of English has deteriorated. Roger Ebert states how reading for him is the most artistic pleasure since the written word creates a world in one's mind. Ebert then talks about how there are people who know how to write and read but choose not to. The panelists then discuss the importance in knowing a second language.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Rita Smith. Perdita Huston begins by stating that women as silent victims are no longer an issue. Hustion then talks about how violence is rooted in a long term cultural attitude. Vesna Kesic discusses violence against in women in wars. Kesic talks about how in modern history there is not a single document that sanctions rape as a war crime. Roberta Fahn Schoffman discusses problems women face in Israel. Roger Ebert questions if men are hard wired to be violent. Ebert then states that many men are violent because that is the way they were built.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Howard Wachtel. Robert Wright begins by talking about what memes are and the history of the term. Wright argues/explains why meme is a very important concept. Wright states that memes are units of cultural information. Ken Goldberg talks about how meme is a generalization of an "idea". Goldberg states why the propagation method of meme is very important. Goldberg then explains how technology can change the process of meme transmission. Roger Ebert talks about how memes comprise the total content of one's mind. Ebert then explains why memes are the cultural equivalent of genes.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Robert Geier. Andy Ihnatko begins by talking about his impressions about the future of cyberspace. Ihnatko questions who is going to own the pipeline that connects people to the internet. Ihnatko then states that one can never really know what they're talking about when discussing the future of cyberspace. Ken Goldberg talks about the differences between virtual reality and telepresence.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: What I've Learned at the Conference on World Affairs
description#1: Robert McClendon recalls trying to get into the University of Wyoming as a person of color. Wendell Harris tells an anecdote about Howard Higman. Joan Higman Davies mentions the lack of international participants. Leslie Green believes that he gained a "sense of humility" from the conference. Sayre Sheldon discusses Buckminster Fuller. Mary Redick recalls her experiences with sexism in academia. Nancy Ramsey also discusses sexism in academia and notes the "importance of students." Julie Fisher recalls going to the conference. Jonathan Broder discusses his first time at the conference. Eric Sterling discusses his first experiences with the conference.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Samuel Shapiro compares Fidel Castro and the Cuban revolution with the abolitionist John Brown in the United States. J.P. Morray speaks to charges against Castro: cruelty, power hunger, long-windedness, treacherousness, deceit. I.F. Stone states that Cuba is the only country to emerge out of anti-colonialism after World War II which went Communist. He says that we made Cuba completely dependent on Moscow, and that Castro is fundamentally an independent person in contrast to the moribund Soviet bureaucracy. John Culver critically remarks on passages in J.P. Morray's book, and also on an article by Samuel Shapiro on which his talk was based. Panel chair Rita Weiss presiding.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The main speaker explains the Apollo program its goal: to send three men to the moon. The machinery will weigh approximately 90,000 pounds and be extremely sensitive to calculations, which are vital for accurate calibration for space travel. The speakers illustrate its components, durability, and how well it will be able to maneuver in orbit and be able bring the men back to the same location on the planet. There will be a central location built for monitoring around the nation as it is on its mission. One speaker describes the Apollo program as resulting from political decisions, such as economy, prestige of the country, and interest to send someone to the moon.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series VI: Survival of the Human Race
description#1: Moderated by Antonette Stepanak. Gerald Mason Feigen begins by talking about the atom bomb and discusses some situations involving nuclear weapons that could eventually lead to war. Gerard Gray Grant explains how all forms of nuclear weaponry involve fallout. Grant briefly mentions two moral elements, use of means and use of force. John W. Spanier talks about how disarmament is not feasible. Spanier states that there is no solution to nuclear weapons, and that people just learn to live with problems as best as they can. William von Eggers Doering suggests that the audience should not let the issue of nuclear weapon, power, or waste recede into the background of their active conscious.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by George W. Zinke. Robert W. DeGrasse discusses how planned economic conversion could help cities transition from economies centered around military expenditure to ones based upon the production of consumer goods, particularly the development of solar energy. Betty Goetz Lall addresses why the U.S. needs conversion and how it could be achieved. Jeannine Honicker states that disarmament needs to begin in the U.S. through the process of conversion.

Marcia Millman describes her experiences following various medical professionals in a hospital for several months, focusing mostly on medical mortality review meetings and malpractice. Mary Redick analyzes medical systems "cross-culturally." Roger Ebert discusses a movie about a man's battle with cancer, his personal experience with doctors, and the novel Blood and Money.

description#1: Moderated by Milton E. Lipetz. Perdita Huston talks about the lives and the families of several villages she has visited in Indonesia, Kenya, Sri Lanka, Mexico and other countries. She explains that she questioned the people in the villages about how the economy and negative or positive change has affected them. Huston also talks about the gap between men and women. She states that it is a fact that for women choices are limited. Huston discusses how she provided the women a chance to voice their opinions.

Greenberg further elaborates on Royko, Green, and Breslin, discusses other well-known columnists, and examines whether reporters could be considered columnists. Eric Lax describes his experience as a columnist. Kenny Weisburg tells an anecdote about Green in Boulder.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Hollywood in the Living Room: The VCR Revolution
subject#3: Motion pictures and teenagers -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Paul Shankman. Roger Ebert begins by showing a clip of Beyond the Valley of the Dolls and then lists the differences between seeing a movie in a theater and watching it on VCR. Michael Stoff discusses some of the pros and cons of using a VCR to play movies for his children, making home videos, and how the VCR has revolutionized viewing pornography. Stoff concludes by analyzing VCR from a historical viewpoint. Lynn Minton discusses the movie-viewing experience, how the VCR has come to replace aspects of it, and teenagers in relation to the movies.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Gordon Gee. Admiral Gene R. LaRocque gives his view on the state of America with relation to national defense. LaRocque argues for a responsible, defensive military, and against a permanent military industry. He also advocates for withdrawing American troops from Europe and Asia. LaRocque ends with a note of optimism, foreseeing the end of the Cold War to be imminent. Questions from the audience follow.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Williams. Michael Stoff presents a history of the "atomic age," and begins with a letter Albert Einstein sent to President Roosevelt about the possibility of the Nazis creating an atomic bomb. Stoff discusses actions during WWII that lead to the Cold War, including the actions of General Leslie Groves, the distrust between Russia and the U.S., the viewpoints of various scientists on using the bomb, and Truman's handling of the bomb. Warren Broderick explores how the atomic bomb influenced scientific communities and governments worldwide by comparing the atomic age and the space age.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Is the Cold War Really Over and What Should We Do About it?
description#1: Former admiral and military analyst Gene La Rocque discusses the role of defense and foreign policy after the fall of the Soviet Union. La Rocque proposes that there needs to be a radical restructuring of the defense apparatus with the demise of the Soviet Union. He argues that there are a number of important issues that should generate more focus in the post-cold war world. He argues that this will be difficult as the end of the Cold War makes many people useless, and that a great deal of profit and influence are tied up with the growth of the defense department for things that are obsolescent.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why is it Impossible to Walk Joyfully in American Cities?
titleSeries#1: Series XXXIII: … in a Meaner and Rougher World
description#1: Moderated by Karl Openshaw. Roger Ebert begins by stating that it's almost impossible to walk around an American city in the same way one walks around London or Paris. Ebert talks about two things that have happened to take away the joy in walking in American cities. Margot explains that the thing that prevents people from walking joyfully is because most of them are not doing what they want to do, and not living the life that they want. Phillip K. Bock discusses how walking joyfully has a lot to do with expectations. Bock then briefly talks about walking down a public street.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Technology and Art: Is It Art?
description#1: David Chamberlain begins by questioning if technology makes better art or less art. David Finkle talks about how theater has become marginalized, and how technology has taken over live theater. Finkle then explains what the microphone has done to live theater. Rob Glaser talks about three issues regarding technology and art. Paul Kolsby states that technology will never melt into art. Kolsby then talks about the differences in technique and technology. Roger Ebert states that all of art and technology are inseparable. Ebert then discusses how technology influences the art that it creates.

She stated the need for "saints and sacrifices" in order to rise above our present condition of malaise. Chairman Joseph R. Smiley presiding.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Private Genius and the Public Weal
description#1: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. Arthur Barber asks the question: Where do we want to go as a society in the future? He addresses problems oriented to Washington D.C but generalizes his points to apply to all society. He believes creative solutions to domestic problems are the best but does not see them being applied. He urges the US government to create a stronger sense of community through inventive techniques, focusing on the US school system as an example. Via a discussion with the audience he determines how the government should re-allocate funds to support the school system better.

description#2: Moderated by Charles Nilon. Joseph Fink states that "the bomb" -- rather than a nuclear weapon -- could be a number of social problems including lack of education, incompetence, or overpopulation. For the first time humanity has changed course from survival to self-destruction. John Migdley discusses a permanent non-proliferation treaty that would prevent all countries from developing nuclear weapons and forbid the five countries that do have nuclear weapons from creating any more. He believes this agreement could only work if the current "nuclear powers" scale down their forces. Charles Nilon refutes some of Migdley's points.

description#1: Moderated by Milton E. Lipetz. Adam Yarmolinsky begins by talking about a few arms control negotiation that the United States is involved in. He explains the purpose of SALT negotiations and provides three explanations on how progress has been made. Yarmolinsky briefly states that no one can win a nuclear war, and that non-nuclear nations of the world are concerned that nuclear powers are not moving rapidly enough towards disarmament. Yarmolinksy ends by stating that we are moving ahead slowly to a more peaceful world and provides four reasons explaining his reasons why.

description#1: Moderated by Patrick M. Woods. Thomas A. Halsted begins by stating that SALT II deals with offensive weapons. Daniel O. Graham states that SALT should be looked at in the context of the number that results on what would really happen if a nuclear war occurs. J. David Singer talks about several criticisms of SALT agreements and mentions that he is in favor of SALT II agreements. Betty Goetz Lall makes six points that has to deal with the SALT agreement. Raymond S. Sleeper points out that there is no arms race and briefly talks about minimum deterrence. Jeremy Stone talks about the effects SALT has caused towards people. Paul Walker provides three possible future SALT legislations. Nancy K. Ramsey ends the panel by questioning what and who national security is.

description#1: Moderated by J. Edward Murray. Daniel O. Graham begins by defining the problem of arms race. David Singer then states the problem of arms race from a different aspect. The panel provides three possible solutions of arms race: first solution from Philip Morrison, second from Betty Goetz Lall, and third from Raymond S. Sleeper. Katherine L. Camp also talks about another solution regarding arms race. Dorthy Gillam Baker discusses the global perspective on nuclear arms race. Thomas A. Halsted talks about problems President Carter faces. Paul Walker talks about what congress should do with respect to the 135 billion dollar budget President Carter has presented. Robert W. Degrasse provides an input on his view towards SALT. Daniel Ellsberg talks about what the average United States citizen should do about arms race.

description#1: Moderated by William Kellogg. George Harris begins by talking about how countries like Pakistan and India do not have the level of trust/willingness to come to accommodation that would be required for the development of a nuclear weapon. Samuel Chavkin talks about the promotion against the idea of nuclear war or nuclear arms proliferation. Jiri Nehnevajsa explains how the threat China faces from the Soviet Union is what operates them to its development in nuclear programs. Nehnevajsa then talks about how agreement in reduction of arsenal is a possibility, but complete disarmament is not possible.

title#1: The Rise and Fall of Intellectual Movie-Going
description#1: Moderated by Maria C. Westkott. David Finkle begins by talking about how intellectual movie-going can be two things: intellectuals going to movies and/or people going to intellectual movies. Finkle discusses how there is no fall in intellectual movies since there are intellectual people still making movies. Roger Ebert explains what intellectual film and intellectual film going experience is. Ebert talks about three things that make movies more realistic. Annie Brody discusses the Hollywood standard of film making. Brody states why film going experiences need to be more meaningful and valuable as a cultural product. Judy Jackson briefly talks about documentary film making.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Open and Closed: Bullies, Hackers, Saints - The Internet Changes It All
description#1: Moderated by Joe Wingerd. Oliver McBryan begins by predicting that internet access will be at the same level as television access. McBryan also predicts that internet access is going to become universal rapidly. McBryan then discusses how video companies and cable companies control a lot of bandwidth. Philip Zimmermann explains how new technology could affect freedom of speech. Zimmermann then talks about the debate of whether cryptography should be available to people. Floyd Cottonberg briefly talks about computer hackers. Roger Ebert discusses a few problems regarding the internet, such as pornographic materials and chain mails.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss the relationship between Havana and Miami in relation to trading, production, purchasing of sugar, and ways to benefit the Cuban economic status. Cuba desired to change its political system (capitalist state) and increase its international communication with nations by investing their money abroad in US or Europe. However, the Americans urged a breakaway of dependence, allowing Cuba to achieve a higher standard of living and economic dependence. However, in attempt to achieve this goal, Americans did not realize that the communists wanted to use the Cuban revolution for its own purposes with soviet aid, dependence, and anger towards the US. Finally, a speaker states the necessity of a new policy that will not result in war but instead provide a chance to prove sincerity between US and Cuban relations.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Stanley Dollins. Van Atta explains what a nuclear test ban treaty could achieve and its potential shortcomings. Gottlieb outlines the political difficulties involved in creating a nuclear test treaty between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Parrish discusses the history of developing a nuclear test treaty between the U.S. and the Soviet Union and the negative military implications of such a treaty. Michael refutes several of Parrish's points and explains how the U.S. resuming testing could have negative consequences for the world. Kalkstein explores the future of nuclear weapons and what the U.S. would hope to gain from a nuclear test ban.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Wesley Posvar. Wesley Posovar introduces the problems surrounding arms control and the effects it has had on the world. George Rathjens discusses arms control specific to the Vietnam War and the Soviet Union. He highlights the differences between arms control and disarmament as well as the history of and changes to both. He explains nonproliferation in terms of international agreements and peace relations between the US and the Soviet Union. Sydney Giffons discusses the proper and improper methods to build an arms-control relationship and Dr. Martinn clarifies the points made by the previous two speakers. Colonel Marshner directly explains the military's point of view on the situation as well as societal misconceptions surrounding the role of the military. Marvin Kochstein explains public opinion and media coverage on nonproliferation. He also discusses the safeguards implemented in weapons testing.

description#2: Buckminster Fuller states that "good" and "bad" are not useful words for mankind. He talks about dividing the world into two parts and what man tends to think about as bad taste using the technique of reduction to absurdity. Gilbert Seldes makes the point that all methods by which taste is changed are themselves changed and this rate of change is accelerating. Charles Butcher posits a strong intuitive feeling that there is something to the meaning of taste, even though there is danger in defining any specific thing as being in good taste. The ability to distinguish "good" from "bad" taste comes from effort -- what works for you. Norman Rudich states that taste is on of the most individual, untranslatable, and mercurial concepts to talk about. Humanizing one's surrounding leads to good taste. Clutter equals bad taste. The question session is poignant and funny. Chairman Paul V. Thompson presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Randolph H. Hudson. Jiri Nehnevajsa believes that the U.S. will develop anti-ballistic missiles, which he views as unnecessary, because of political pressures put on the Presidential candidates in the coming election. Isador I. Rabi outlines the social, economic, and technological factors regarding the ineffectiveness of an anti-ballistic missiles system. Velma Linford states that the money that would have gone into building an anti-ballistic missile system would be better invested in a variety of social improvement programs.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers here discuss what it means to be a conscientiousness objector in regards to war. The first speaker defines it as one who refuses to be in allegiance with military service. However this person can and often will find an alternative civilian manner in which to make up for this refusal of participation in the service. The reasons for refusal could be due to religious training or beliefs, which are strong enough to place a sense of responsibility upon the person to not enter the armed forces. The choice deals with what the majority believes on war versus moral imperatives.

description#1: The Vista Program is a model for volunteer service in America, uniting all forms of government. This program allows volunteers to go into a new community, and be given a project with a sponsor who holds a job in heavily poverty stricken areas, many of these being rural. The speaker urges that to integrate America, people must reach out through this creative partnership and enable people to feel their own worth.

Blue starts by stating that there is a lack of diversity in the arts and discusses his involvement with the Rice Media Center and public television to help combat this. He shows video clips from various films: one by a black high school student talking with her blind aunt, another by the Coalition for Barrier Free Living showing people's struggle with mobility, and a final film produced by Blue called Who Killed the Fourth Ward?

subject#6: Dow Chemical Company -- Rocky Flats Division
description#1: Moderated by Forrest W. Williams. Daniel Ellsberg begins by describing his beginnings with the Rocky Flats Truth Force and the legal battles regarding their petition. He uses the overthrow of the Shah in Iran to illustrate how non-violent protest can be successfully used against powerful enemies. He also discusses the dangers of low-level radiation and the reason why the Rocky Flats Plant poses a health hazard. Then, Ellsberg tells some personal stories from his experiences with the Rocky Flats Truth Force. He also states that nuclear weapons were being produced at Rocky Flats and discusses nuclear war.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Is Criticism in the Arts Useless?
description#1: Moderated by Sherry Wallace. Gene Lees begins by talking about the subjectivity of criticism. Lees discusses why criticism is not necessary. Nick Brignola talks about whether critics are valid and explains why he believes criticism is necessary. Frederick C. Tillis talks about how consumers of art should develop critical judgment. Tillis then explains why lack of knowledge is the most serious problem of criticism. Roger Ebert talks about how critics are subjective and explains why critics can't be objective. Ebert states that he writes for movie-goers and not for movie-makers.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Galm. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how movies have too much music. Marian Edmunds questions if reality should be underscored with music. Edmunds also questions if film and music can collaborate, and still remain art forms of their own integrity. Johnny Mandel briefly talks about scoring the news. Mandel then explains why there is a lot of music in film today. Dave Grusin talks about why music is put in film for various reasons, and states that the underlying reason is to manipulate how one feels. Grusin then answers Edmunds question regarding film and music collaborating.

description#1: The speaker explains the processes of presidency and public rule. Including questioning by public poll, the period of primaries, and lastly, the convention. Validity of arguments by critics results in measurements of a presidency whether or not a candidate has the capacity to be able to organize support, manage publicity, and keep ambition and goals for higher achievement. Cater concludes his session by expounding on the presidential use of power, and characteristics of leadership.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Peace Corps, Food and Skills--Tools for Development
description#1: Rather than debating power and policies, the differences between the two systems, communism and democracy, are discussed. The capabilities of free systems includes providing sympathetic understanding, moral support, and material aide to developing nations. Herein it is posited that citizens should be able to enjoy a minimum standard of living by improving primitive economies. With freedom results peace; thus, leading nations must share resources and skills for others to solve own issues. Understanding the difference of communist and democratic philosophies will allow for a stable democracy, starting at a local level.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: United Nations as a Changing System
description#1: The discussion explains the function of the United Nations secretary general, needed when extreme fluctuations and changes occur due to tension of the world. The secretariat is comprised of the secretary general, who is the chief administrative officer of organization and is appointed by the UN general assembly. The General's role is to harmonize and strengthen international relations and actions. For the future, the secretariat might look at defining the rule of power in nations, and presenting in specifics what they are in favor for.

subject#2: Cold War -- Political aspects -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Omer C. Stewart. J.P. Morray outlines the history of containment. Calvin Dietrich argues for containment and refutes the basic principles of communism. Joseph W. Angell Jr. gives an alternative account of the history of containment and explores the consequences of containment. Noel Parrish states that the U.S. government has supported leaders they believed would not "brutalize" their nation's people, but these leaders have often turned against the U.S. Thus, U.S. intervention and containment are necessary.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: This is a panel discussion about the types of generals entrusted to retain order and peace, either mercenaries or aristocrats (in the 18th and 19th century) as at the time, that was the best way to get into the officer corps. It was said, and a commonly held belief, that generals possessed divine guidance and intuition following from hereditary lineage. Professionalism and confidence was necessary while competing with other nations, and compromise was necessary while moving between old and new systems. The speakers end the panel by featuring different military organizations and emphasizing the importance of their work and interaction with students on college campuses.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speaker focuses on the importance of Israel's national existence since 1948 and the desire for independence. This has resulted in negative struggles such as the Nazi period and elimination of aid centers for the Jews. Independence has also led to immigration, accompanied by the problems intertwined with population and economic growth. Thus, the national purpose has turned to focus on fusion, which is why work has begun on educational opportunities regardless of class for a new economy. Working towards peace, the speaker claims that the Middle East will always be an area of diversity, emphasizing that a citizen must be equal in democratic cities despite his class and/or religion.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Reduction of the Risks of War
description#1: Moderated by Charles Nilon. Alexander Zinchuk discusses different strategies regarding how the U.S. and the Soviet Union can avoid war. Jiri Nehnevajsa explores the issues in trying to reduce the risks of nuclear war and the reasons that would cause it. Stanislaw M. Ulam describes the "layman's view" of the risk of nuclear war. Robert E. Matteson lists possible causes of nuclear war and the agreements (or lack thereof) between the U.S. and Soviet Union regarding nuclear war.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Creative Process: Stimulus and Response
description#1: Creativity is composed of two parts: the creative act and society's response. The creative process has to be distilled from a point of interest, through which society uses languages, art, etc., allowing for communication. This process requires a high degree of specialization to derive truth from different point of views and to retain the importance of the individual in society. The speakers conclude with the causes and results of creativity, improvements for society and individuals, and creativity's ability to change thought patterns and lives.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss the tasks of members in the press, and what they report in the news, such as the Washington Post. There are various techniques with which the government and those in executive positions use to communicate with the people, primarily: press conferences and releases of information communicated to the public. There are informal sessions in which such are debated; however, the speakers argue that all people have the right to know what is going on but not the right to participate in the deliberations. This is where the press' job comes in, because they depict what occurs in the deliberations

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Kenneth R. Hammond. Marvin Kalkstein discusses abandoning the arms race and reducing our level of weaponry. Global and US methods for reduction are explained. Harold Agnew challenges Kalkstein and proposes viewing armaments in terms of new defensive and offensive systems. Joseph Angel describes the hypertrophic and hypotrophic perspectives on arms control. He suggests an arms control solution would be the creation of a supreme organization that could determine the necessity of arms to different countries. Saul Padavar explores the psychology of violence that propels countries to fight each other.

title#1: The angry, unskilled, unemployed, uncommitted young men
description#1: (tape 1: cwa_65-54) @00.02 Bob Turner introduces Charles Butcher, @2:35 Charles Butcher talks @20:57 Butcher ends @21:22 Bob Turner introduces Leslie Fiedler @22:39 Leslie Fiedler talks @36:55 Fiedler ends @37:33 Bob Turner introduces E. description#2: Charles Butcher, speaking as a conscientious objector, describes three groups of people that represent the population of the United States (while removing articles of clothing) -- 1. college students, dropouts, beatniks, and streakers; 2. "trash" i.e. poor people; 3. "smug-uglies" i.e. the rest of us. He describes the sources of anger of the first two groups, and what each group should do about it. Leslie Fiedler asks if the youth of the United States should be considered an oppressed minority. He speaks of psychological exploitation by groups in power, and the replacement of traditional masculine roles by feminine ones. E. James Lieberman describes adolescence and gives statistics of youth in the United States. He talks about programs that provide useful employment and experience for disadvantaged youth. Jean Kern talks about the frustration of the poor caused by rejection and lack of job opportunity. Chairman Bob Turner presiding.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: United States Policy in World War III
description#1: Moderated by Leslie Fishman. Caryl Conner is the interviewer for a mock Presidential Debate. Charles Butcher is playing the Peace Party Presidential Candidate. Arlo Tatum is the Democratic-Republican Coalition Presidential Candidate. Questions include topics such as the Vietnam War, rising Communist governments, the national debt, admitting China to the UN, overpopulation, biological and nuclear warfare, foreign aid, building an anti-missile system, and cooperating with the U.S.S.R. in space exploration. In the end, Tatum is "elected."

description#1$1: Moderated by Theo Volsky, Jr. Kent K. Parrot makes comments on the various developments in armament in the Soviet Union and the U.S. Anthony Hartley believes that an anti-ballistic missile system would make no difference in securing the U.S. Edward P. Morgan agrees with Hartley, adding that ABM is simply "part of the problem." Robert Goulard mentions the secrecy of the government regarding armament.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Speaker Veronica de Negri discusses the state of democracy and human rights in Chile. She recounts her personal experience as a Chilean exile, and the death of her son at the hands of the Chilean government. She focuses on the struggle of political opponents in Chile, particularly that of women and children. De Negri's brings up the role of torture, murder and intimidation used by the Pinochet government. Her dialogue implores the audience to consider the role of the US government in supporting the Pinochet dictatorship, and in understanding how it underscores human rights violations in Chile

description#1: Moderated by Rita Weiss. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how science fiction has created a sensibility of satire, reverence, rejection of authority, irony, and cynicism. Whitley Streiber states that he is not a science fiction author and explains why he is angry at science fiction. Streiber then talks about why the failure of science fiction is the failure of science. John Gliedman begins by stating that Streiber is totally wrong. Gliedman then briefly talks about science fiction in the 1950s. Charles-Gene McDaniel talks about why he can't stand science fiction novels. McDaniel states that science fiction can be an important instrument for criticism.

subject#4: Nuclear weapons -- Social aspects -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Maurice Albertson. Irving L. Horowitz explores the military, economic, social, and political difficulties in finding a solution to the arms race. Noel Parrish refutes Horowitz, pointing out that nuclear weapons would not be used to kill civilians and that the Soviet Union continues to resist inspection. Jiri Nehnevajsa also disagrees with Horowitz, stating that Americans do not view the arms race in "black-and-white perspectives" and that there is no sinister force at work in the U.S. government that perpetuates the production of nuclear weapons.

description#1: There is an attempt to construct a communist society with peaceful coexistence, which means recognizing social systems with the right to form a government they desire. Thus, improving relations between socialism and capitalism as well as removing dangerous sources of war. Beginning in 1953, the United States and the USSR have managed a peaceful coexistence with steps toward deduction of military expenditures, ending arms race, and have achieved disarmament as a result of the test ban treaty. Contacts and exchanges between nations have broadened, and the speaker claims that the two countries have every reason to live and work together in peace, with no war and a profound community of interests based on mutual goals.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speakers discuss what it means to be an intellectual in nations such as the United States and Britain. It is reasoned that it involves one's political allegiance, leading from university to often work in government. The role of an intellectual is described through society's expectations, and one's work, performance, and interests. One speaker claims that the word 'intellectual' is more of an adjective than a noun in the US because it is almost a profession here, a way to self-recognize. All agree that the work and focus of an intellectual is in the life of the mind.

description#1: Moderated by Robert E. Day. Norman Rudich discusses the merits of entertainment and people's attitudes towards entertainment, patriotism, politics, and indifference. He focuses on the film "Doctor Strangelove" and its critical reception versus that of "My Fair Lady." He gives an in-depth analysis of the characters. Joseph Angel explains "black humor" and gives his criticism of the film. Harold Agnew discusses the military's relevance and parallels to "Strangelove." Donald Wiseman uses poetic language to explicate the film's impact on pop culture and his own life. All speakers analyze the character of Jack D. Ripper in terms of nuclear war.

subject#2: Indians of North America -- Politics and government -- United States
description#1: @00:07 host introduces panel and topic @20:15 discussion open to questions from floor @46:30 Flies High begins @56:15 Flies high ends / open panel begins @1:44:01 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Floyd Westerman. The panel discusses the history and consequences of political activity by Indians. They agree that Indians must be fairly represented by a government that provides education, improves the economy, and supports political activity. Speakers suggest that education of Indians will free them of federal controls and allow them to preserve their culture. Issues discussed include fishing rights in western Washington, governance of reservation services, and empowering Indian students during their education.

description#1: @00:19 Bob Jacobs introduces Robert Moog @1:58 Moog begins @41:00 Moog ends @42:02 open for question among discussants (Kizer, White and Rosenberg) @1:01:52 opens for audience @1:22:42 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Robert B. Jacobs. To Bob Moog, electronic music is a medium of musical expression. Electronic music results from the "generating of sound material", as well as the control of sound, its storage and recording. He explains the creation of composition through parameters of pitch, amplitude and timbre. Using a synthesizer, Moog demonstrates variations in sound as pure pitch vs. pure noise (e.g., white noise), as transient variations, and through filtering to modify tone color. In composition, he emphasizes the importance of the distribution of sounds as an expression for electronic expression. The variations of sounds are enhanced by modern materials and technology, demonstrating the relation between computers and electronic music.

The students are agents of change who represent the character and needs of the society in which they find themselves. He compared student movements in America and Europe and spoke to what the universities can do to provide a university experience which will enable the students to recognize their potential. He focuses on the current difficulties in China under Mao Zedong and the Communist Party and the abuses of the Cultural Revolution. He closes by describing his hopes for the future of China without Communism and the assistance that the United States can give in achieving that end. Chairman Warner Imig presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Philip L. Krauth. Roger Ebert begins by talking about how only a part of the new age is a con game. Ebert briefly compares magicians and spiritualists. Chip Howells talks about two appealing aspects of what is leaked into the new age: traditional spiritual notions and the powerful new scientific discoveries. Myra Pearson discusses why she doesn't have anything positive to say about the new age. Mark Kramer explains why he thinks the new age is paradoxical. Kramer then talks about how new age language is a use of some special ecological opportunity that language presents.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#2: Arms race -- Economic aspects -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Earl W. Phillips. Charles Butcher argues that a government agency should be created to convert weapons facilities into factories for consumer goods and retrain workers for new positions. Paul Jacobs argues that trade unions have no position on disarmament because the government has not outlined a plan for the economic displacement of workers involved in armament. R. Buckminster Fuller discusses the Great Depression. Butcher returns to state that economic displacement really "isn't a problem." Jacobs returns and uses San Francisco as an example of why economic displacement is a serious problem. R. Buckminster Fuller returns and says he believes the GI Bill from the Great Depression will return in the form of fellowships.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#3: Nuclear warfare and literature -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Thorrel B. Fest. Joseph Fink discusses the possible causes of "accidental thermonuclear war" between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Irving L. Horowitz contends that the chances of accidental war are very slim. Joseph W. Angell discusses films and novels related to the Cold War and points out that they all assume that the military is "psychotic." John Midgely argues that "discontinuity in the government" in either the U.S. or the Soviet Union can result in accidental war. G. Deane Davis states that accidental war is highly unlikely and that films and novels about the Cold War are "science fiction."

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by James G. Allen. Harold M. Agnew states that, depending on world events, the U.S. will fluctuate between building up arms and decreasing arms. Walter Goldstein argues that the "semblance of stability" between the U.S. and the Soviet Union will be upset when other countries with less stable governments obtain nuclear weapons and that a non-proliferation treaty is necessary. James L. Tuck states that he is more concerned about developing nuclear energy than creating nuclear weapons. Agnew and Tuck have a discussion about the feasibility of complete disarmament and the future of nuclear technology. Agnew and Goldstein have a discussion about other governments obtaining nuclear weapons.

His last target is the shortcomings of U.S. colleges. Throughout this talk Taylor points out the similarities between the young and restless all over the world. The talk ends with a call to the young to begin a revolution. Chairman Stanislaw Ulam presiding.

description#2: Moderated by Margaret Robb. Beginning with readings of modern poetry, the speakers express a sense of loss in the American experience expressing society in tension with idealism. Modern society seems to expect humans to be analytical and temperate in emotions, but the cry of the natural man seeks expression. Differences in older vs. modern poetry include the diversity of poets, who create language with new meanings and interpretations. For example, the speakers discuss several African poets as adherents of the school of "negritude" in modern poetry. Poetry is often comparative, beginning with an observation, then comparison, and then the verse.

title#1: The Department of Defense on the Defensive
description#1: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. Edward P. Morgan argues that there isn't a military-industrial complex, but a "military-industrial-political complex" that has come under fire. Some of the criticisms of this proposed complex include political biases that influence government funding, the misappropriation of government funding for military expenditures, and gross underestimates of the military budget.

description#1: Calvin Dietrich explains why a nation-state is infeasible and lists some indirect benefits of the Cold War. James Avery Joyce states that the mass media must become more objective and that the Cold War cannot be solved with military action. J. Richard Goldstein argues that communications between nations must be improved and that the Cold War stemmed from competition between the U.S. and Russia. J. P. Morray believes that the Cold War began as a problem within the two nations. Fred Warner Neal discusses the Soviet position on the Cold War and the misunderstandings between the two nations.

description#2: Adam Yarmolinsky speaks about the analogy between the Vietnam War and the War on Poverty as a long struggle against tyranny. Both seem to be a long way away. He describes the War on Poverty as largely an opportunity to prepare for, get, and hold a decent job. We, as a nation, have the wealth to eliminate poverty. He cites examples of successful programs in the War on Poverty in the United States. He talks about monetary and debt management policies, and mobility and communication techniques. Chairman E. Robert Turner presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Max S. Peters. Norman Cousins begins by briefly talking about the death of General Douglas McArthur. Cousins then questions how the United States can provide security for Japan, Philippines, and etc. He also questions if arms are working. Cousins then provides an example of where arms didn't work too well. He states that just getting rid of arms isn't good enough, and states that it's necessary for something to take the place of the arms. Cousins ends the panel by stating that he believes America still has time to think/act to justify the great gift of life.

title#1: Anti-Ballistic Missiles - Through Thick and Thin
subject#2: Nuclear weapons -- Environmental aspects -- United States.
subject#3: Nuclear weapons -- Defense measures -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by Adrea Rosenberg. Samuel T. Cohen describes the logical fallacies used by those for and against building an anti-ballistic missile system. H. Prescott Sleeper believes that the money that would have gone to building an anti-ballistic missile system should go towards finding peaceful applications of nuclear energy and that the use of nuclear weapons, especially in the atmosphere, could possibly have grave consequences.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Freedom and the Creative Imagination: The Negro Literary Ferment
description#1: The speaker claims that African American authors have been unable to escape racial stereotyping. However, he highlights a writer who has moved beyond anger and has developed concerns for his or her craft in relation to the larger world of art and ideology. Literature has been a medium through which African Americans can explain racial situations, arriving at a new self perception and self definition in relation to the world. The speaker urges writers to experiment with means of expressions to bring richness and diversity to the field, regardless of race.

titleSeries#1: Series XII: How many days for NATO
description#1: Moderated by Vincent W. Beach. John Midgley covers Dulles's ideas about war with the Soviet Union and the historical role of NATO. Gordon P. Savill states that the U.S. will probably choose to not escalate the conflict if the Soviet Union attacked Western Europe, which concerns Charles de Gaulle. Berndt von Staden argues that, in the past, the Soviet Union was willing to take greater risks, but that is not the case now. This change in Soviet policy should be used to further attempts at disarmament. Kenneth B. A. Scott outlines strategies for Western Europe in the event of war with the Soviet Union.

subject#1: Eisenhower, Dwight D. (Dwight David), 1890-1969 -- Political and social views.
description#1: Moderated by Earl Young. Andrew Knight summarizes Eisenhower's message, which cautions people about the rise of the military-industrial complex and its ability to obtain more power than it already has. Philip Geyelin goes over military expenditures and lists some of the indirect benefits of developing weapons. Michael S. March states that the government should not try to destroy the military-industrial complex, but control it. (Some portions of this recording are partially indecipherable. identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Bramsen. Miroslav Soukop begins by talking about a general concept regarding mutual accommodation and extermination. Soukop introduces two concepts concerning culture system, social system, and personality system. Richard Felger talks about how extermination is like extinction. Felger then states that there is no way to measure the values of another species. Arden King questions how the concept of environment brings people a little bit closer to understanding themselves. King ends the panel by stating that in any animal, the question of survival lies in the accommodation within their environment.

Vadim Loginov outlines the Soviet Union's position on arms control. Leslie C. Green argues that arms control is impractical because, historically, arms control could only be established with weapons that were outdated at the current time. identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by E. James Archer. Rothschild outlines his points: the desirability and possibility of banning particular weapons of war, specifically the toxic (chemical and biological) and nuclear weapons; and methods of ensuring the obsolescence of war in the future. Rothschild gives a general history of weapons-use and then focuses specifically on toxic and nuclear weapons. Negative effects and the humane nature of toxic weapons are explained, as well as their effectiveness against enemies. Suggestions are given for the eventual elimination of weapon-use and the prevention of war altogether.

description#1: The speaker urges the importance of understanding what our system requires, rather than using substances to remedy a feeling or pain without knowledge of the substance. The panel gives examples of various types of psychoactive drugs and their psychological effects. Moreover, they discuss how one is able to function in society with or without taking such substances. The causes and effects, as well as the cure, if any, for those who take these addictive substances are discussed and considered by the panel.

titleSeries#1: Series VIII: No Art This Year
description#1: Moderated by David L. Paulson. Peter M. Mayer mentions various art forms, how they fail to cause political action, and the possibility of video tapes to change this. Mayer and Roger Ebert discuss the future of books. Ebert lists the various types of political films, with emphasis on Jean-Luc Godard's films. Leonard C. Ball argues that films "mean nothing" and that "the arts have always been politicized." The panelists discuss creating "revolutionary films," how films are geared towards middle-class America, the future of the video tape, and the growing diversity of actors. The panelists have another discussion about Black protagonists in movies and Jean-Luc Godard.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Berkley M. Sterling. Sam Rosenberg states that current movies "offend him," citing that current movies feature too much nudity and there are fewer pictures worth seeing. Hayden V. White lists some rules regarding types of movies to avoid. Roger Ebert argues that new movies are simply "a new way of doing an old thing" and explains some film conventions and how they are changing. The panelists discuss how the pace of movies is increasing, the difference between watching a movie on television and in the cinema, their interpretation of the title of the panel, and the five worst movies of 1969.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Military Industrial Simplex: No Feedback
description#1: Moderated by Lawrence G. Weiss. Joseph Kraft begins by stating the aspects of military industrial complex that makes it look like a pure force for advocacy. Kraft mentions that the military industrial complex isn't all that big in the United States and states that it's a political reason for why it looks potent. Scott Payne starts by agreeing with Kraft and extends some of the remarks he made about the military industrial complex  absence of countervailing forces, appeal to patriotism for more money, and large share of federal budget. Reginald Duwarem states the differences in military in France compared to the United States and mentions that military in France are a nationalized industry.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Fiction is Dead and Awaiting Burial
titleSeries#1: Series XVI: Art, Literature and Drama
description#1: Moderated by Nancy Bush. Roger Ebert states that we need to appreciate novels by all authors, not just ones by "respectable authors," and that fiction is still alive in various art forms, including novels and films. Roger W. Wescott plays devil's advocate and states that fiction is dead because of society's emphasis on science, but believes that fiction (through play) has been a part of mammalian behavior for millennia. Joseph W. Angell Jr. argues that fiction plays three purposes: fiction is a substitute for reality, fiction interprets reality, and exceptional fiction can be a reality. Angell also believes that many new novels lack originality.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Robert Kroepsch. Roger Ebert believes that society might be trying to liberate itself from "American, middle-class concepts of marriage" that include property, legally binding documents, children, stereotypical gender roles, and divorce. He proposes that alternative forms of marriage, such as communal marriage and common law marriage, might help address these issues. Ebert begins a discussion with the audience about the possibility of women keeping their last names, reasons for getting married, factors that contribute to the success or failure of a marriage, accepting change in marriage, new trends in marriage, sexual incompatibility, affairs, open marriages, women with jobs, and equality.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Are We Breeding for Our Oblivion
description#1: The speakers illustrate the importance of birth control and population control. As well as the importance of educating children, usage of medicine, and the awareness of the social aspects that can affect and result from population growth. One of the speakers argues that the scientific curve should be applied to the field of fertility control to avoid population booms in the future. Actions must be taken for population control, especially for those who are less equipped (financially or otherwise) for parenting. As we increase scientific and technical capacity to invent the future, there must be an increased focus on predictions for the social arena and monitoring population growth.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The oil industry is not only valued by the Middle East, but also by the United States, Asia, and European nations as they all depend on the production of oil. The large revenues derived from oil production in the Middle East, allow many people to become wealthy and the goals of the oil companies are to improve national economy, and develop increased industry and agriculture. The speakers state that money which goes to the banker of the oil company will in turn be able to improve poverty, which is the current trouble of Middle East. The hopeful aim of these oil companies and nations is to better security and justice, living standards, and increased availability of education.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John Major. Victor Isakov discusses a potential future nuclear co-op and the draft treaties on nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. He speaks from the perspective of Russia and compares their policies to those of the United States. Richard Scott speaks on the drafting of a treaty to prevent the continued spread of nuclear weapons and which countries have been active in its development. He discusses cooperation between the governments as a key point in the development of a nonproliferated world. Jerry Page details the recent history of nuclear weapons and the rapid changes that the world has undergone. He questions what the world will look like if proliferation continues. Jacquard Rothschild discusses a United Nations strictly for weapon control to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and promote disarmament. He details what we need to do in order to avoid war.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: A Pax on Both Your Houses
description#1: Moderated by Keith E. Davis. Elizabeth Farmer discusses the morality of the US position in Vietnam. In a Q+A with the audience, she explains the place of morality in generalized foreign affairs and imperialism. Sanford Gottlieb also discusses foreign affairs in terms of morality, and Victor F. Isakov talks on the necessity of concessions in war. Farmer speaks on genocide and the use of force to protect minorities. Each speaker generally addresses the topics of morality, use of force, and protection of civilian rights through organizations like the United Nations.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jack Crouch. Jacquard H. Rothschild argues that complete disarmament is the only true solution to prevent a "nuclear holocaust" since this is the only way to guarantee that the weapons will never be used. Berndt von Staden believes that disarmament can only happen in small gradual steps and that any steps toward disarmament must maintain the current balance of power. Joseph W. Angell Jr. states that a far more devastating "World War III" could have already occurred had atomic weapons not been developed and used as deterrents.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The speaker explains the goals of the new constitution (1954) of Pakistan after the failure of the old (1947). It is estimated that the failure of old constitution was due to lack of proper elections, leadership, and undue interference by head of state. Whereas, the new constitution focuses on social reform and economic development, in which the system separates power between the executive and legislative branches of government. There will be a division of power amongst the executive, legislative, judiciary in attempt to foster national unity as well as solve future conflicts over issues such as: elections, budget proposals, change in amendments, and citizen equality.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Social Basis of the Radical Right
description#1: The radical sides are not the majority, yet they attempt to move Republicans more to the right because it controls most of the money and votes, which has resulted in success of republicans in general elections. The right fights for religion, patriotism, and freedom; as well as social groups based largely in middle class and rural communities. Even in the early Roosevelt days, the radical right opposed organizational support of society. The speakers argue that the radical right has done all the wrong things to obtain power and expand their voter base.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Storm Bull. Thomas Brimelow outlines the history of the Red Army in the Soviet Union, particularly Stalin's attempt to establish political control over the Red Army. G. Deane Davis discusses the military-industrial complex in the U.S. Brimelow returns to speculate what the military-industrial complex is like in the Soviet Union. Alex Campbell compares the military-industrial complex in the U.S. and the Soviet Union, but also states that they share some similar components which he calls the "research-and-development complex." Brimelow responds to Campbell's thoughts about the Soviet military-industrial complex. Davis goes into the history of the U.S. Air Force and industry. [Tape cuts off before Davis finishes.]

description#1: Moderated by Reuben Zubrow. Harvey Averch describes the economics of deterrence and post-attack economics. Rudolph Winnacker discusses how the military can continue its current expenditures without "militarizing our society" and how "peace through strength" can deter future war. Clarence Ayres explains why limited civilian consumption  not military spending  is the cause of slow economic growth. Richard Miles talks about the effects of nuclear war on Great Britain and whether Great Britain should continue its nuclear weapons program.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Hilton M Power. In the last session of the conference, Rudolph Winnacker discusses the impracticability of thermonuclear war between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. In addition, Winnacker argues for "peace through strength" by maintaining nuclear weapons in order to deter future war. The majority of time is spent answering questions from the audience regarding the possibility of other countries obtaining nuclear weapons, potential changes in warfare, the likelihood of disarmament, the future of the Soviet Union, U.S. foreign policy with the Soviet Union, and the effects of a nuclear attack.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Negro Political Behavior in the South
description#1: There are many dynamics at play in southern states after desegregation and granting the right to vote to African Americans. Economic changes will surely follow. The speakers posit that the social dynamics underlying segregation and discrimination must be improved through an assimilation of African Americans into middle and upper classes, which will in turn help to eliminate conflicts between races as well as classes. However as the speakers state, the lack of potential leaders makes it difficult to comply with registration, and it is vital for leaders to arise to effect change.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series I: The United Nations: 25 Years Later
description#1: Moderated by Houston Wearing. Zenon Rossides begins by defining what disarmament is. Rossides states that disarmament is a subject that concerns all countries for the survival of humanity. Then, Reginald Duwarnt starts by saying that the French believe in disarmament. Duwarnt gives an explanation on why the French didn't sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty. George Sherry talks about the development in the disarmament field. Sherry states that all effective progress in the field of disarmament is not disarmament, but the control over weapons/arms to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. Burner Meinhoff concludes by saying that feasible wars are conventional wars, and nuclear weapons should never be used.
