identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Robert C. Hanson. Roger Ebert argues that it is the purpose of art to stimulate people, including in prurient ways, and that pornography can be used as a catharsis for society. William Braden states that we should allow pornography in the arts. Zenon Rossides offers his opinion of the definition of art and believes that we should create art that "elevates man."

title#1: TV: The Man With The Power Saw
description#1: Moderated by Albert Smith. Roger Ebert argues that seeing a movie on a screen is superior to watching it on the television. Norman I. Gelman believes that the radio and movies provide better entertainment and news than the television and lists some of the benefits of television. James Stokely proposes that society should attempt to improve the quality of programming on television. The panelists discuss the inferiority of television.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Anthony Ripley. Speakers discuss how the media uses personalities to shape our beliefs and devise new sources of information. As the audience, we encounter a cult of personalities, based on a fantasy presented to us -- not based on what they do. Celebrities gain name recognition and fame when the press selects individuals to present to the public. The speakers conclude that the press, through negative publicity, becomes a saleable commodity and no longer functions as a public service. Television becomes a business to sell the most time for money.

description#1: Moderated by Larry Baccus. Roger Ebert notes that movies have become increasingly violent over the years, and although he states that is a fan of certain violent movies, he does not approve of "movies that excite through the exploitation of bloodshed." Alisdair Clayre believes that violence in the media has led to a more violent society since the media emphasizes "violence without the rule of law" and that this generation needs to "rediscover" lawful violence. Lamar T. Empey offers some demographic information about crime and victimization in urban areas.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Fuller presents the hypothesis that humanity has something that no other creature has: mind. This allows us to discover relationships between ideas rather than having to depend on those ideas by themselves. Because of this, we must be here for some reason: to be problem-solvers for the universe. This has been Fuller's drive for the past several decades. Fuller believes that humanity is in a time of extraordinary crisis. He provides a brief history illustrating the links between power and shipping, from ancient times through Magellan to the founding of the East India Company. He then describes the links from this to Malthus and Darwin, then to Karl Marx, and the roots of the two great theories of capitalism and socialism that now have the capacity to destroy all life on this planet within minutes. Next Fuller describes the variety of forces that affect our lives, most of which we are completely unable to sense directly. From there, Fuller lists the development of materials that humanity has invented to deal with those forces and put them to use for us. He continues by describing the differences between tension and compression. Fuller brings out his tensegrity sphere to illustrate these differences, and spends some time describing how the tensegrity sphere works, and how it relates to his geodesic dome designs. Fuller then relates that in 1970, he realized that the Earth has enough resources to provide an excellent standard of living for all human beings, what that means for politics, wars, etc., and the great challenge of trying to communicate this to everyone. Next, Fuller points out a wide range of logical fallacies that are made by the general public, with a bit of nerdy humor thrown in as well as a detailed exploration of geometry. He then makes some lengthy remarks relating to humanity's place in the universe, given recent advances in standards of living as well as the development of technologies capable of destroying all life on Earth. Chairman Arnold Weber presiding.

description#2: Moderated by Stuart M. Takeuchi. Crime around schools has increased due to the presence of gangs and readily-available drugs. Also, changes in family demographics and the accessibility of firearms have resulted in less discipline and moral guidance. Social changes among the poor result in a loss of community, which further inhibits economic and educational opportunity for young adults. Flaws in the justice system also inhibit the rehabilitation of juveniles. Therefore, we should empower social institutions to instill positive values and reduce delinquent behavior. The speaker asks: Are juveniles to blame for increases in violence, or does the failure lie within society itself? Society should strengthen and support families as they try to provide guidance and discipline.

title#1: U.S.Vietnam Relations After the Lifting of the Embargo
subject#2: United States -- Foreign economic relations -- Vietnam
description#1: Moderated by Philip Distefano. Speaker, and first secretary to the UN delegation from Vietnam Vu Khac Nhu discusses the normalization of the relationship between Vietnam and the United States. He gives this talk as a forerunner to the opening of the Vietnamese embassy in Washington D.C. Vu Khac Nhu reviews the historical and practical reasons that normalization of relations has been delayed, such as the Vietnam war, MIA's, and frozen assets on both sides. He makes the case for a stronger relationship between the United States and Vietnam, such as business, trade, and travel rights for Vietnamese Americans.

description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the role of diplomacy and intervention in foreign policy and decision making. Speakers discuss how transparent the use of secret diplomacy and covert intelligence in policy decisions should be. The panel also discusses when it is appropriate to use military intelligence, and how policy decisions should take intelligence into account. The effectiveness of current policy and the role of the media in dealing with intelligence matters are also discussed.

description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the varieties and methods of providing foreign aid, and talk about the methods of getting the best results. They discuss the changes in providing aid that have occurred in the last few decades, and debate whether the results have been beneficial. Panelists discuss various problems, such as aid being stilted in local bureaucracies, misunderstanding of the skill-sets and knowledge of indigenous people, and the conflicting interests of aid providing countries.

description#1: Michael Straight speaks about the ideology of communism from the standpoints of history, politics and personal experience. He talks about the birth and death of a faith and its stubborn refusal to die as a result of fear of alienation and isolation. He speaks to the difference between ideology and faith and the literary works that describe this era in history, i.e. the death of a butterfly. Chairman Kaye Howe presiding.

description#1: Moderated by Robert J. Hefling. Christopher J. Makins begins by stating some policy problems governments and people face in situations where disarmament is not preceded very satisfactorily. Makins briefly talks about how regional arms control regiments would create stable balance between countries that are in political conflict. Patrick M. Morgan discusses the general notion of deterrence, and the flaws/weaknesses in that concept. Morgan also mentions the key central elements of deterrence. Alexander S. Yerekovsky ends the panel by stating that the Soviet government has a policy in the area of disarmament and limitation of arms in order to prevent a nuclear war.

description#2: Moderated by Russell Shain. Toby Eady expresses his disdain for producing television nature documentaries and briefly touches on media in Europe. Edward P. Morgan argues that reporting and journalism sometimes use illusions to create sensational news stories. Roger Ebert finds that new filmmakers are great at making exciting films, but unfortunately do not make many films regarding "the human experience." Max Lerner believes that today's media cannot create "mythical heroic figures," and as a result, today's people are less able to identify with heroic figures. Lerner also mentions that television networks and the press have too much control over what is produced.

description#1: @00:04 Neal begins @48:06 Neal ends @48:50 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by William E. Briggs. The speaker explains the American and Soviet quest for détente, which seeks respect and improved relations between both sides to protect their core interests. Détente aims to achieve a stable international situation and to prevent thermonuclear war. The speaker lists four American views of détente: those who oppose any agreement, those who want détente with the Soviets, those who support all agreements, and those who seek a mutual agreement. Détente might increase trade, enhance military power, improve relations with China, and relieve misconceptions that nations have of each other.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#2: Sex discrimination in employment -- United States.
description#1: Moderated by John Dunn. Nancy Abrams notes the lack of women in science and uses premature birth research to illustrate the different views men and women can have. Sonya Hamlin states that men dominate many workplaces, because men are taught, from a young age, how to be successful in the job market while women do not receive the same informal training. Roger Ebert mentions that, for the past ten years, the winners of the Academy Award were male actors portraying regular men, while the female winners portrayed either political figures or prostitutes. Chad Gordon discusses sociological research on divorce, marriage, and gender roles.

description#1: The panel of speakers discuss the ideas of Pierre Teilhard de Chardin. Discussion includes whether Teilhard de Chardins ideas have become viable, or if time still needed to gain perspective on them. Discussed are Chardin's thoughts on the goal of human evolution and the cosmos, and whether there will be a greater unification of consciousness. The implications of contemporary issues in technology, and the intersection of science and religion are brought up as issues affecting the way Teilhard's ideas can be thought about.

description#1: Paulo Lazzareschi talks about the political and economic history of Brazil over the last 18 years. Lazzareschi discusses the political coups and uprisings since 1964, discussing the reforms and character of the varying regimes. He ties this to Brazilian economic development over this time period, and discusses the possible political and economic troubles Brazil could face in the future.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: India: Under the Sainthood-A Closer Look at Mahatma Ghandi
description#1: A panel of speakers discuss the legacy of Mahatma Ghandi in India and in the realm of non-violence in the light of a recent film on Ghandi. Speakers review if Ghandi is more successful as a saint or a politician. Debated is role of Ghandi's thought in the history of India, particularly in the separation from the British Empire, and whether his thought still has importance in contemporary Indian society . Analysis is given to what effects events in Ghandi's life had on his thought and leadership.

subject#4: Freedom of the Press -- Great Britain
subject#5: Freedom of the Press -- United States
subject#6: Mass media -- Moral and ethical aspects
description#1: Moderated by Michael Tracey. The panel discusses the problems and societal effects of the contemporary press. Speakers discuss the ways the press is too restrictive in some areas and overreaching in others. Themed around "freedom from the press", specific topics of discussion include the moral obligation of the press, privacy, the burden of consensus in publishing, and the consolidation of media sources and loss of quality local news sources.

subject#1: Educational tests and measurements -- United States -- History -- 20th century
subject#5: Intelligence tests -- United States -- History -- 20th century
description#1: Moderated by Milagros Caraballo. Speaker Nicholas Lemann discusses the rise of standardized testing in bringing about the rise of meritocracy in the United States. He gives an overview of how meritocracy became associated with success in America, opposed to older forms of getting ahead, such as class and birthright. Lemann addresses the problems of the current system of meritocracy, and what the outcomes of the system have been, opposed to what they were supposed to be. He finalizes the talk by giving his thoughts on whether the meritocratic has been the right path to success in American society.

title#1: Time for a New Cruasde Against All Fanatics
description#1: Moderated by Dalene Beaver. Roger Ebert begins by recalling his first exposure to the concept of equality in Catholic school, exploring the increasing tribalism in the U.S., the various minority groups in the U.S. who feel they have been wronged in some way, and the decrease of open-mindedness of the U.S. educational system. George S. Harris discusses various types of fanaticism in the U.S. and across the globe and urges for moderation. Robert E. McClendon discusses the history of Armenia and how its people insist on perpetuating a religious war without thought to their own wellbeing.

title#1: Higman: A Collection and the Birth of the Conference
description#1: The panel starts with a video of audio clips from various panels. Tom Adams recalls his experiences with Higman and the process of writing Higman: A Collection. Roger Ebert describes his reaction when he learned he would be writing the introduction to the book, discusses his memories of Higman, and introduces "witnesses" (university professors from different departments) who have been present for the majority of the 50 years of the CWA: David Hawkins, James Deugan, Adam Larbolinski, and Ken Hammond. Ebert, Leslie Green, and Betty Brandenburg discuss a variety of topics. Higman family members give their thoughts on the CWA.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by James G. Allen. Ralph Lapp, the main speaker, describes the effects of nuclear fallout and radiation on an individual's health. Lapp refers to the health effects from the aftermath of Hiroshima and to hypothetical nuclear situations of various levels. Due to time constraint, Harrison Brown very briefly agrees with Lapp. Aaron Novick discusses the negative genetic effects of nuclear radiation. Lapp then speaks again, emphasizing a realistic view on the potential of nuclear disaster. Questions from the audience follow.

description#1: Moderated by Francis A. Beer. Christopher J. Makins begins by stating that the North Atlantic alliance is both a military and political organization. Makins explains the significant trends that have been occurring within the military organization of NATO, and also provides the political aspect of alliance. William L. Eagleton talks about how the alliance was set up to defend a group of countries against dangers from the Soviet Union, and not for problems amongst its own members. Patrick M. Morgan discusses the problems that cause debate in the military aspect of alliances. Richard C. Samuel ends the panel by making a brief comment about extra European affairs.

description#1: Moderated by Peggy Tague. Patrick M. Morgan begins by talking about the major reasons why SALT is under attack, and the current American political debate and issues in SALT talks. Alexander S. Yereskovsky emphasizes the significance of the treaties and the business going on between the United States and the Soviet Union. Robert Pickus shares his opinion that governments cannot lead to the direction of arms control and disarmament because their first responsibility is to secure society. Felix Moos states that the problem in strategic arms limitation for the Soviet Union and United States is a national perception.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Thomas Bird. Tom DeVries recalls the type of person Allard Lowenstein was: a political activist in the National Student Association who always seemed to know what was going on. Roger Ebert states that Lowenstein was "a marker in [his] life" and discusses his personal encounters with Lowenstein. Ebert also believes that DeVries is a marker in his life and recalls how they met. Paul verbalizes his thoughts and memories about Lowenstein. DeVries returns to discuss Lowenstein's contribution to the Dump Johnson movement.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: The participants give an overview of the emergence of the "information society". Participants talk about how the current information society differs from previous societal paradigms such as industrial and agriculturally based societies. The speakers discuss the possible necessary and unavoidable outcomes of the transfer to an information society, such as educational understanding, the effects on jobs, the poor, and those without access. All of the discussion is done in the context of understanding on how changes in content and the information container interacts with the human condition.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Speakers Peter Lupsha and Sam Papich discuss organized crime in America. Discussed are myths about organized crime, such as its actual activities, ethnic makeup, and geographical distribution. A theory of the current model and paradigm of contemporary organized crime are proposed. A historical overview of organized crime dating back to colonial America is given to explain the contemporary structure and process of organized crime, particularly in its relationship to the political system and corruption.

He also explains why no one in America would buy an American car. Ebert ends the panel by talking about laser vision discs.

description#1: Moderated by Peter Spear. Paul Kolsby argues that classics are first romantic in their time, discusses "Offending the Audience," and lists classic moments from literature and movies. Sayre Sheldon gives her criteria for a classic and asks the audience if any novel on the New York Times Bestseller List could become a classic. Jingalu describes what a "classic" is from an Aboriginal perspective. Wendell Harris believes that there are no classics because there is no "common core of information." Roger Ebert concurs with Harris, discusses reading classics, lists some of his favorite classical authors, and explains the various levels of culture.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Cecil Effinger. This is the first of five panels in the World Affairs Conference of Disarmament. Harvey Averch argues that "Western values" have created a "philosophy of force," creating "symmetry" through nuclear stalemate. He proposes alternative strategies hinging on arms control and diplomacy while still maintaining some nuclear weapons as "deterrents." Feigen asserts that the U.S. and the Soviet Union should not have the power to use weapons that will spread radiation across the globe and that a greater number of nuclear weapons increase the chances of "accidental war." He also argues for diplomacy and a world government like the UN. Averch returns to talk about systems analysis, emphasizing the importance of inspection in maintaining arms control.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Constitution--The Living Versus the Literal
description#1: The speaker's argument is that increasingly, decisions are being carried out by the Supreme Court and that the executive is becoming only the packager of legislative programs. Also, recently there has been a decline in the role of parties in bringing together factions and compromising in issues such as national security, policies, and the economy. Thus, there has been a rise in individual groups pressuring political agendas through manipulating propaganda, resulting in the decline of power for political parties. This brings with it the concern of editorial power and news filtration. Looking at this issue, suggestions for improvement range from creating a sub-government to having a quota system.

title#1: Function of Literature in Emergent Nations
description#1: @00:04 host introduces panel and speakers @3:12 Simon begins @10:52 Simon ends / Eady begins @18:10 Eady ends / Bock begins @22:58 Bock ends / Moos begins @33:45 discussion with panel and audience begins @1:09:30 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Robert E. Day. For countries newly emerged from colonialism, the speakers propose that literature can shape the lives of the nation and produce revolutionary change. The speakers speculate that literature may result in the growth of society, when literature relates to the rest of the world. Literary means can educate people about society and the integration of ideas. The speakers contend that we must understand the basic needs of society, rather than fight over politics. One speaker claims that writers in many Southeast Asian nations express the lives of their countries by writing about their people.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Message to the Media for the Third Century
description#1: @00:02 host introduces speaker @3:10 Morgan begins @31:14 Morgan ends @44:46 tape ends
description#2: Moderated by Eugene H. Wilson. The speaker claims there is a gap between the people and the media, which is not doing their job: they fail to inform the public and they promote controversy. He claims that news is being filtered through a person's voice and face by 2 elements in the media: sight and sound (television and radio). Instead, he contends that the media should document issues at the heart of our national security, such as improving education. He feels that news stories should relate to the public's interests. He concludes that knowledge, constructive controversy and genuine enlightenment fuel the government by the people and for the people.

titleSeries#1: Series X: The Job of Sex
description#1: Moderated by J. Russel McGoodwin. Pepper Schwartz discusses what being a prostitute is like and how this affects typical male-female relationships. Roger Ebert notes that all of the past nominees for Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress had women portraying royalty or whores. Schwartz returns to state that women must find an identity that is in-between the Madonna-whore complex. Sonya Hamlin discusses how her sexual fantasies were ignored by her partner and how creating fantasies is beneficial. The panelists discuss vibrators, long-term relationships, sexual incompatibility, sex counseling, and communication between partners, the purpose of prostitutes, pornography, sadomasochism, and homosexuality.

description#1: Moderated by M. John Loeffler. Christopher T. Cory begins by briefly introducing himself. Then, Bonnie S. Hyra explains her definition of flexi-time and states 7 ways jobs can be divided. Christopher T. Cory talks about restructuring the balance between the demands of work and production. Cory then briefly talks about the satisfactions received from a job. Sonya Hamlin speaks from personal experience and discusses why flexi-time is necessary. Hamlin also explains how flexi-time opens up possibilities. Jane Howard talks about her lifestyle as a free-lance writer.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: China After Mao-Death of a Resolution
description#1: Speaker, professor Ralph Buultjens(New School) talks about the influence of Mao Zedong and his political philosophy in shaping China during the 20th century. He argues that Mao was a historically unique figure in history for his depth of influence in decisions that shaped the current Chinese state. Buultgens argues that with the death of Mao, the Chinese state is undergoing further enormous changes, such as rapid modernization that will have a global impact.

description#1: In a diverse panel discussion about the relationship of music and language, changes in music syntax and theory are discussed from several academic perspectives(music theory, anthropology, computer science). These experts in various fields discuss the relationship between music and language and if there are distinct similarities between the two. Heavily discussed are the connections to linguistic theory(particularly Chomsky) and whether such ideas can be imported into thinking about music.

description#1: Moderated by Lewis Sawin. Howard Mills begins by reading and discussing a passage from Lady Chatterley's Lover written by D. H. Lawrence. Sayre P. Sheldon talks about how Lady Chatterley's Lover was her sex education. Sheldon explains why feminists dislike Lawrence. Sheldon then discusses how Lawrence saw sex as the male domination of the female. Katherine Neville talks about how all the books she has read that's written by Lawrence have male characters that are very intriguing. Roger Ebert explains why the keyword in the title, Lady Chatterley's Lover, is "lady". Eric Lax reads and discusses passages from a few novels.

description#1: Moderated by Laura Marshall. Roger Ebert begins by talking about why there are not a lot of Hollywood movies about families. Ebert then states that families are not taken seriously in American films. Kathryn Olney talks about her search for the perfect crossover movie. Charles-Gene McDaniel explains why he blames the decline of good manners on television. McDaniel then discusses how Hollywood has not caught up with the rest of the world in depicting different races and sexual orientations in films.

title#1: C60 Buckmisterfullerenes: the celestial sphere that fell to earth
description#1: Moderated by Joseph H. Romig. Harold Kroto discusses the history of molecules and chemistry. He explains the structure of molecules and revolutions in how people view them. Kroto shares the specific techniques involved in discovering the Buckeyball molecule and the exploration of its structure. Kroto details his struggles with studying the molecule and how it came to be named the Buckeyball.

description#1: Moderated by Dani Newsum. Lael Segall begins by questioning where civil society came from. Segall then makes an assumption that the features of civil society may have been prescribed by a particular culture in a particular time in history. David Finkle explains how there is some form of integration in society when there is disintegration. Finkle then states how civilization has found a way to put a break on the disintegration of humanity. Finkle briefly talks about how fear makes the world go round. Roger Ebert explains how tribalism is the biggest social disease in the world today. Ebert then discusses how most of the people who are against abortion are women.

description#1: Moderated by Jane Lowenthal. Harvey Wasserman begins by explaining why he chose to get rid of his television set. Wassermann expresses concern about why the most addictive drug of all, television, is not banned at all. Wasserman discusses the addictive and destructive powers of television. Roger Ebert talks about how he spends a lot of time on the computer. Ebert then discusses how the passivity of sitting in front of a television set has been replaced by the ability to surf the web. David Finkle talks about how headlines can change much more often with television.

description#1: Moderated by Norwood Robb. Andy Ihnatko discusses Microsoft's failures in programming, gives a personal anecdote about the incompatibility of Microsoft software with other operating systems, and displays a machine that he can control with his Mac. Roger Ebert describes why Microsoft is a successful company, recalls his initial frustrations with Windows, and examines why Windows dominates the business world. Richard Stallman argues that all computer industries are involved in unscrupulous business practices and mentions the development of free software. Tod Nielsen lists the "Top 10 Lessons" he learned from Bill Gates.

description#1: From 1956-1959 there was a founding of a new more progressive middle east  changing with experiences to benefits the middle class and raise the standard of living; thus, contributing to better health, longer lives, and more education. The speaker argues that Arab socialism is much different than the Marxists socialism, noted differences being: a face of nationalism connected with industrialization, health programs, land reforms, and expanding education. In addition, he speaks of industry, foreign aid, manufacturing, and private enterprise for economic development.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by John F. McMahon. Richard Fryklund starts by exploring the possibility of creating a NATO counterforce that would focus on targeting Soviet nuclear weapons in order to avoid a nuclear war targeting cities. Stanley Reed covers the reasons why NATO was founded. Fryklund discusses the why a NATO counterforce would be infeasible. Harvey Averch states that nuclear weapons should only be used "in direct retaliation" or in "the defense of the free world" and that a NATO counterforce is a better alternative to nuclear warfare. Noel Parrish mentions how previous and current attempts to build up a conventional force in Europe have failed, reasons why a large conventional force will never be amassed by Europe, and how nuclear warfare as the only option. A discussion between the speakers follows.

description#1: Moderated by John Carnes. Noel Parrish states that banning nuclear weapons testing would not lead to peace since it would upset the "symmetry" of force which exists between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Alexander Zinchuk's greatest concern with test bans is the possibility of one nation getting ahead in the arms race and how inspections would be conducted. Donald Michael posits the creation of an anti-missile missile system and argues that China could be stopped from obtaining nuclear weapons. J.P. Morray states that the Soviet Union has tried to establish a test ban with the U.S., but the U.S. has refused to discuss the issue. Parrish returns to discuss the distinction of offensive and defensive weapons, test bans, and China. Zinchuk refutes Parrish.

description#1: Moderated by Ulrich Goldsmith. Toby Eady believes that people who criticize art should be able to analyze the entire process of making art, not just final result. Jim Burnes describes the process of creating his work of art: a man driving through a wall of televisions in a convertible. Roger Ebert discusses Chris Burden and his works and asks the other panelists to report this as if they were journalists. He continues and describes what the media did when reporting on one of Burden's works called Doomed. The panelists discuss the process of making sensational news stories.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Avoiding War in the Third Century- Is There an American Role
description#1: Moderated by Harry Carlson. Robert Pickus begins talking about how he doesn't expect the government to lead towards a world without war. Pickus is more concerned on what people/society has to say. He states that society plays a crucial role in America's progress to a world without war. In order to have a world without war, Pickus suggests that one must know the minimal conditions  disarmament, law, sense of community, and response  essential to that role. He ends by stating the most important task in the third century, which is to help establish a world community that can resolve its problems without mass arms.

description#2: Moderated by John P. Lymberopoulos. The speaker raises environmental awareness to promote a healthier and cleaner environment for all species. She describes societal expectations of corporations since the 1900s and our dependence on industry. She explains environmental regulations, passed to regulate problems and improve environmental quality. Corporations, she claims, are valued for the goods and services they supply; however, in terms of economics, political power, and environmental effects it is our responsibility to monitor corporations. Lastly, she emphasizes that environmental acts are standards for the country and that corporations must meet and preserve these standards.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Albert W. Smith. The United Nations held a special session devoted to disarmament, and Katherine L. Camp discusses the details of that plan. William Epstein talks about how the small powers are the only ones interested in disarmament, and the large powers are not. However, Thomas Karas states that all nations are interested in disarmament and explains his reasoning. Nancy K. Ramsey talks about the distinct difference between arms control and disarmament. Ramsey hopes arms control will lead to disarmament but questions if it will ever happen. David Singer ends the panel by talking about the topics that was discussed earlier by the other panelist in more detail.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
subject#1: Nuclear energy -- Environmental aspects -- United States
description#1: Moderated by Berkley M. Sterling. Jeannine Honicker begins by stating that nuclear power is a nightmare of radioactive garbage. Honicker tells her reason on why she opposes nuclear energy. Paulanne Capavitz disagrees with Jeannine. Capavitz states that using nuclear energy is a peaceful application, and the real danger lies in using nuclear energy as a weapon. John Gliedman talks about how nuclear power is not more dangerous than other ways of generating energy. Gliedman suggests that we must distinguish between short term and long term effects of nuclear power before making extreme actions like closing down all plants.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Alan Shapley. J. David Singer begins by stating that both the United States and the Soviet Union doesn't have a global strategy. Philip Morrison states that strategic doctrine is largely a rationalization of complex political process with many non-analyzable inputs. Raymond S. Sleeper talks about how America thinks strategy comprises only warfare. William Epstein explains how global strategy is not solely military strategy, but military strategy is the most important element of any global strategy. Anne H. Cahn ends the panel by informing the audience to write to the congress/senate to have SALT III ratified.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: Why I am a Computer Zombie
description#1: Moderated by Dana Leibsohn. James Jackson discusses the use of computers when writing. The panelists are distracted by Roger Ebert's "lap portable." Jackson returns to tell his personal experience with using a computer and how it inspired the name for this panel. John Gliedman discusses the evolution of the computer and his personal experience with using a computer, downloading software, and using a lap portable. Roger Ebert makes many comments about computers including various personal anecdotes, how the lap portable has revolutionized writing, the difference between various word processing programs, and online communication. Jackson returns to further elaborate on online communication.

description#1: Moderated by Kevin M. McMahon. Roger Ebert begins by discussing Showscan, going to see Joe Mantegna in a play, and comparing and contrasting the movies with theater.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Cost and Worth of the Military Industrial Complex
description#1: Moderated by Mary Wolff. Robert McClendon describes the process of producing military equipment and machinery. John Gliedman discusses some of the problems plaguing the world and the U.S., particularly economic scientific issues in the U.S. Gordon Sumner Jr. argues that the military-industrial complex requires "an overhaul" financially and politically, but also points out that the research labs within the military-industrial complex most engage in research that is useful for the general public.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Marie Fagan. Miroslav Nincic begins by talking about various ways in which engineering can create a stable and long term solution to arms race. James T. Bush states that the problem lies in the United States and Soviet Union losing any rational for building nuclear weapons. Bush also states that there is no logical end to the arms race. Charles Hauss states that the solution in the long run to the arms race is to build a shift to a new way of thinking. Peter Pringles ends the panel by talking about how the arms race was created.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Barry Satlow. Jurek Martin begins by stating that television has a large public service element in it, but is somewhat both a public and private service. Martin talks about television in three different countries  Britain, Japan, and United States  based on his experiences. Mose Durst discusses religion and media. Durst states how television has been used as an instrument of bigotry rather than public service and enlightenment. Roger Ebert talks about how television as a medium is an inefficient way to communicate political, religious, and philosophical ideas because television has abandoned words for images. Both Durst and Ebert believe that television is not a public service.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
titleSeries#1: Series III: What is Wrong With the USA
description#1: Moderated by Stephen Foehr. Roger Ebert begins by talking about ethnic jokes and stereotypes. Ebert talks about how in American movies, it is ok to be prejudice against the Arabs, Japanese, and Germans for humor. Robert E. McClendon talks about three incidences that have happened regarding racism. McClendon then talks about the definition of racism. McClendon discusses personal problems he had faced for being black. McClendon ends the panel by explaining the color hierarchy in Thailand and how fear is associated with darkness.

description#2: Moderated by Dusty Blades (James N. Corbridge, presiding). All panelists begin the session with a satirical performance of British newscast. Martin then criticizes the current state of the British monarchy as becoming too much like celebrities and unnecessary for the British people. The rest of the panelists agree with Martin in criticizing the functions and publicity of the British royal family. All panelists speak in a humorous tone. Questions from the audience both criticize and support the panelists' positions.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: What is Technology Doing to the Way We Communicate?
description#1: Moderated by Kathleen Campbell. Sidney Pike begins by discussing a few predictions regarding the future and population of the world based on his experiences with new technology Pike also predicts that English would be the only language spoken. Roger Ebert talks about how new emerging forms of communication such as emails have impacted him. Ebert explains why telephone is the greatest waste of time in modern civilization. Ervin Duggan talks about the greatest moral and human danger of new technology. Sonya Hamlin explains why people are product orientated people. Hamlin then states that technology should be used for research, and not for communication.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
title#1: The Legacy of Star Wars: The Force is With Us
description#1: Moderated by Daniel Sher. Andy Ihnatko begins by talking about the Star Wars opening crawl. Ihnatko then talks about Star Wars in detail. Paula Pesman discusses why Star Wars is a familiar film drama people could relate to. Pesman then talks about the legacy Star Wars has left, such as the visual effects. Pesman explains how Star Wars found a way to introduce religion and faith to children. Jeff talks about whether "the force is still with us," then discusses what the "force" is. Roger Ebert talks about the making of Star Wars. Ebert also questions what the "force" is and states that the force is extremely shallow and meaningless. Rodion Nahapetov talks about the impact Star Wars had in Russia.

identifierSource#1: CWA/Archives, University of Colorado at Boulder
description#1: Moderated by Jack H. Crouch, Buckminster Fuller defines the terms "synergy" (where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts) and "energy" (the actions of the individual parts). Fuller explains how synergy is an important concept, drawing on examples from chemistry, the human body, the educational system in the US, geometry, and pattern recognition. Finally, he states how synergy can be applied in engineering and architecture.
